2018-06-14.snippet: Why has President Trump’s charity faced years of legal scrutiny? And what does the New York attorney general’s lawsuit against it mean?
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the New York State attorney general sued the Donald J. Trump Foundation, charging it with “improper and extensive political activity, repeated and willful self-dealing transactions, and failure to follow basic fiduciary obligations or to implement even elementary corporate formalities required by law.”
2018-06-14.headline_main: The Donald J. Trump Foundation, Explained

2018-06-14.abstract: An inspector general report gives President Trump new ammunition to criticize the F.B.I., but it does not fit into his theory that agents conspired to help Hillary Clinton.
2018-06-14.snippet: An inspector general report gives President Trump new ammunition to criticize the F.B.I., but it does not fit into his theory that agents conspired to help Hillary Clinton.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s inspector general on Thursday painted a harsh portrait of the F.B.I. during the 2016 presidential election, describing a destructive culture in which James B. Comey, the former director, was “insubordinate,” senior officials privately bashed Donald J. Trump and agents came to distrust prosecutors.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Report Criticizes Comey but Finds No Bias in F.B.I. Decision on Clinton

2018-06-14.abstract: Don’t know anything about soccer, but know you’ll be forced to care? We’ve got you covered.
2018-06-14.snippet: Don’t know anything about soccer, but know you’ll be forced to care? We’ve got you covered.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: The World Cup started on Thursday. You may not be the world’s biggest soccer fan, but you want to at least pretend, right? Excellent. We’ve got you covered. Here is our six-step plan to sounding smart wherever you might be watching the 2018 World Cup.
2018-06-14.headline_main: How to Talk About the World Cup and Sound Reasonably Smart

2018-06-14.abstract: The only major U.S. orchestra that requires skirts makes an exception for its parks concerts, which on Wednesday featured two preteen composers.
2018-06-14.snippet: The only major U.S. orchestra that requires skirts makes an exception for its parks concerts, which on Wednesday featured two preteen composers.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic, the only major American orchestra that doesn’t permit its female players to wear pants for formal evening performances, makes an exception for the popular concerts in the city’s parks. So it appeared that many of the women had jettisoned their usual skirts on Wednesday, when the Philharmonic came to the Great Lawn at Central Park on this year’s tour.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Review: The Philharmonic’s Women Can Wear Pants in the Park

2018-06-14.abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: Lisa Zeidner’s review of “The Country Life.”
2018-06-14.snippet: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: Lisa Zeidner’s review of “The Country Life.”
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Jenny Offill reviews Rachel Cusk’s new novel, “Kudos,” in this week’s issue. In 1999, Lisa Zeidner wrote enthusiastically about “The Country Life,” Cusk’s third novel and American debut. Read an excerpt below.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Notes From the Book Review Archives

2018-06-14.abstract: After years of focusing primarily on pinot noir, winemakers in the Willamette Valley have turned their attention to chardonnay with excellent results.
2018-06-14.snippet: After years of focusing primarily on pinot noir, winemakers in the Willamette Valley have turned their attention to chardonnay with excellent results.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Last summer in the Willamette Valley, I had the chance to ask a renowned Burgundy producer, whose Meursaults are some of the greatest wines made of chardonnay in the world, why Oregon’s chardonnays had improved so dramatically over the last decade or so.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Chardonnay, the Oregon Way

2018-06-14.abstract: Gamblers flocked to Monmouth Park and the Borgata to be among the first to wager on sporting events in New Jersey.
2018-06-14.snippet: Gamblers flocked to Monmouth Park and the Borgata to be among the first to wager on sporting events in New Jersey.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: The line formed at the Borgata casino well before 11 a.m., the designated time that sports betting was set to begin on Thursday. There were a few gamblers who were prepared to wager thousands of dollars, and many others who wanted to make bets that were much more modest, arriving simply to be part of a moment that felt historic.
2018-06-14.headline_main: You Can Now Place Sports Bets (Legally) in New Jersey

2018-06-14.abstract: Donate, protest, call — and, eventually, vote this cruelty out of office.
2018-06-14.snippet: Donate, protest, call — and, eventually, vote this cruelty out of office.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: It may be hard to believe that this is happening in the United States in 2018, that hundreds of children are being snatched from their parents, frequently under false pretenses, often screaming, and placed in vast warehouselike centers like the former Walmart in Brownsville, Tex., where nearly 1,500 boys now spend their days. The parents often don’t know where their children are, or when they will see them again.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Seizing Children From Parents at the Border Is Immoral. Here’s What We Can Do About It.

2018-06-14.abstract: As officials tried to ensure a warm welcome for World Cup fans, a lawmaker warned that women should avoid sex with foreigners, especially those from other races.
2018-06-14.snippet: As officials tried to ensure a warm welcome for World Cup fans, a lawmaker warned that women should avoid sex with foreigners, especially those from other races.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In recent weeks, Russia has been engaged in a concerted effort to tame its habitual xenophobic demons in anticipation of 500,000 foreign soccer fans descending on the country for the World Cup that started Thursday. It has even organized classes on how to smile.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Russia Wants to Play Nice With Foreigners. Just Not Too Nice.

2018-06-14.abstract: This week, refugee chefs take the helm at local restaurants to celebrate their foods and cultures, in an effort that started in Paris and has spread to 13 more cities.
2018-06-14.snippet: This week, refugee chefs take the helm at local restaurants to celebrate their foods and cultures, in an effort that started in Paris and has spread to 13 more cities.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, in a basement kitchen in the NoLIta neighborhood of Manhattan, a cheerful woman in blue sneakers and pink-striped leggings chopped piles of parsley and mint leaves, making quick work of it with her 12-inch chef’s knife. Rings on, hair up, she was testing a new Iranian-style falafel sandwich for the menu of Taim restaurant.
2018-06-14.headline_main: A Festival Where Refugees Cook for New York

2018-06-14.abstract: Following a series of reforms, and subsequent crackdowns, in recent years, women in Saudi Arabia are poised to gain the right to drive this month. We want to hear about women’s lives there.
2018-06-14.snippet: Following a series of reforms, and subsequent crackdowns, in recent years, women in Saudi Arabia are poised to gain the right to drive this month. We want to hear about women’s lives there.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Long known for its highly patriarchal laws that limit women’s freedom, Saudi Arabia may be turning a page. In a first, the ultraconservative kingdom issued driver’s licenses to 10 women in early June, several weeks before the authorities planned to officially end the ban on women driving.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Are You a Woman in Saudi Arabia? Tell Us How, or if, Your Country Is Changing

2018-06-14.abstract: The electronic music producer unites sounds from across Portuguese-speaking Africa into a unique style of dance music.
2018-06-14.snippet: The electronic music producer unites sounds from across Portuguese-speaking Africa into a unique style of dance music.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: QUINTA DO ANJO, Portugal — Across the River Tagus from central Lisbon, at a venue surrounded by fruit warehouses and storage units, one of Portugal’s most exciting dance music producers was deep in concentration behind the decks. She was not banging out electronic beats at a sold-out club, however. A crowd jostled around a buffet table. In the corner stood a tiered cake. And the producer’s mother was busy pouring glasses of sparkling melon wine and showing guests family photographs on her phone.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Nídia Is Bringing the Sound of Lisbon’s Ghettos to the World

2018-06-14.abstract: After watching “Ocean’s 8” and “Killing Eve,” we wonder: Is our current cultural climate — specifically around this #MeToo moment — making space for more dynamic women characters?
2018-06-14.snippet: After watching “Ocean’s 8” and “Killing Eve,” we wonder: Is our current cultural climate — specifically around this #MeToo moment — making space for more dynamic women characters?
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: After watching the blockbuster hit “Ocean’s 8” and BBC America’s cat-and-mouse drama “Killing Eve,” we noticed some similarities in these leading women — they’re all “bad.” They’re indulgent and driven. They care about their work more than your feelings. They perform for each other more than they do for men. (Do they even perform for men?) They’re complicated, and that’s why we like them. So we wonder: Is our current cultural climate — specifically around this #MeToo moment — making space for more dynamic women characters?
2018-06-14.headline_main: We Need Bad Women

2018-06-14.abstract: An inspector general report faulting me also found no evidence of bias or improper motivation in the F.B.I. investigation of Hillary Clinton’s emails.
2018-06-14.snippet: An inspector general report faulting me also found no evidence of bias or improper motivation in the F.B.I. investigation of Hillary Clinton’s emails.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice’s independent watchdog, the inspector general, has released a report that is critical of my decisions as F.B.I. director during the investigation of Hillary Clinton’s email account. The report concludes that I was wrong to announce the F.B.I.’s completion of the investigation without coordinating with the attorney general and that I was wrong to inform Congress in late October that we had reopened the investigation.

2018-06-14.abstract: Beyond the Battery and the Great White Way lies Broadway’s less-traveled northern stretch. A walking tour and photo essay reveal its many treasures.
2018-06-14.snippet: Beyond the Battery and the Great White Way lies Broadway’s less-traveled northern stretch. A walking tour and photo essay reveal its many treasures.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: I am three blocks from the Broadway local subway stop, just past West 204th Street. Right before me is a time machine, capable of transporting me back to when most of Manhattan north of Canal Street consisted of hilly meadows, orchards and plowed fields. The Dyckman Farmhouse and Museum is the oldest remaining farmhouse in the borough, made of fieldstone, brick and white clapboard with a gambrel room and Dutch door, dating from about 1783 — a magical stop on Broadway’s least-discovered northern stretch.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Untrodden Broadway: The Hidden Gems of a World-Famous Street

2018-06-14.abstract: North Korea aired video on state television on Thursday that shows President Trump greeting a North Korean general with a salute.
2018-06-14.snippet: North Korea aired video on state television on Thursday that shows President Trump greeting a North Korean general with a salute.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Footage of President Trump saluting a top North Korean general during this week’s summit meeting with the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, set off debate on Thursday over military and diplomatic protocol.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Trump Saluted a North Korean General, Setting Off a Debate

2018-06-14.abstract: Ms. Cotton was a leading campaigner for voting rights in the Deep South and was with Dr. King in Memphis during his final hours.
2018-06-14.snippet: Ms. Cotton was a leading campaigner for voting rights in the Deep South and was with Dr. King in Memphis during his final hours.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Dorothy Cotton, a confidante of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. who was the only woman in his inner circle of aides, marched in perilous civil rights demonstrations and was a driving force in getting Southern black people to vote, died on June 10 at a retirement home in Ithaca, N.Y. She was 88.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Dorothy Cotton, Rights Champion and Close Aide to King, Dies at 88

2018-06-14.abstract: Fifty years ago, a jury convicted America’s favorite baby doctor of abetting Vietnam War resisters.
2018-06-14.snippet: Fifty years ago, a jury convicted America’s favorite baby doctor of abetting Vietnam War resisters.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: In the national memory of 1968 — dominated by images of student protests, police riots and assassinations — the Boston conspiracy trial of Benjamin Spock, the world’s most famous baby doctor, and four other antiwar activists is too often forgotten.
2018-06-14.headline_main: When the Government Went After Dr. Spock

2018-06-14.abstract: Mindfulness makes people less motivated.
2018-06-14.snippet: Mindfulness makes people less motivated.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Mindfulness meditation, a Buddhism-inspired practice in which you focus your mind entirely on the current moment, has been widely embraced for its instrumental benefits — especially in the business world. Companies like Apple, Google and Nike provide meditation rooms that encourage brief sessions during the workday. Chief executives publicly extol its benefits. And no wonder: The practical payoff of mindfulness is backed by dozens of studies linking it to job satisfaction, rational thinking and emotional resilience.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Hey Boss, You Don’t Want Your Employees to Meditate

2018-06-14.abstract: I set out to write a warm, whimsical book about a black girl’s hair. Twenty years on, that’s still a powerful subject.
2018-06-14.snippet: I set out to write a warm, whimsical book about a black girl’s hair. Twenty years on, that’s still a powerful subject.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: When I was a little girl, I loved the moments I spent with my mom as she did my hair — not so much getting my hair combed, but the ritual around the process, and the magic we created out of it. First, the banishment of annoying siblings to another part of the house. Then, the gathering of materials: a turquoise wide-tooth comb and brush set, an assortment of candy-colored barrettes, and the jar of blue Ultra Sheen hair grease, a small cup of solidified ocean that bore the swirling imprint, like fossilized waves, of dipping fingers. Finally, there were the stories. We pretended there were people who lived in my hair, and as she combed each section, we’d “visit” our regular cast of characters — usually based on real-life friends and relatives — creating elaborate story lines about the goings-on in their lives. Sitting between my mother’s knees I could be and do anything. I felt powerful.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Why Do Kids’ Books About Black Hair Draw So Much Attention — and Controversy?

2018-06-14.abstract: Prosecutors dropped a groping case against the former head of the Italian soccer federation, concluding that his accuser was too old to be distressed.
2018-06-14.snippet: Prosecutors dropped a groping case against the former head of the Italian soccer federation, concluding that his accuser was too old to be distressed.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: ROME — In Italy, sexual harassment is a young woman’s problem.

2018-06-14.abstract: Fighters backed by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates pushed toward the Yemeni port city of Al Hudaydah. The Saudi crown prince watched the World Cup.
2018-06-14.snippet: Fighters backed by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates pushed toward the Yemeni port city of Al Hudaydah. The Saudi crown prince watched the World Cup.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Fighters backed by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates pushed toward the Yemeni port city of Al Hudaydah on Thursday, on the second day of a battle that analysts say could be the bloodiest of the Yemen war.
2018-06-14.headline_main: As Saudis Go to War, the Crown Prince Attends a Soccer Match

2018-06-14.abstract: Showtime’s and perspective- and time-fracturing soap opera returns for a fourth season of sex, death, psychological baggage and 24/7 childish behavior.
2018-06-14.snippet: Showtime’s and perspective- and time-fracturing soap opera returns for a fourth season of sex, death, psychological baggage and 24/7 childish behavior.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: “The Affair” returns Sunday for a fourth season on Showtime, still playing its game of battling points of view and shifting timelines. It opens with the show’s best pairing: an episode seen half through the eyes of Noah (Dominic West), former husband, and half through the eyes of Helen (Maura Tierney), former wife. She remembers him swearing repeatedly in front of their children and putting a beer on her tab. He remembers her telling their daughter that Daddy now lives on the same street where Charles Manson killed all those people.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Review: ‘The Affair’ Is Back, and Things Are About to Get Crazy. Again.

2018-06-14.abstract: Few of President Trump’s measures to slow illegal immigration have attracted more opposition than the crackdown that is separating many migrant families at the border.
2018-06-14.snippet: Few of President Trump’s measures to slow illegal immigration have attracted more opposition than the crackdown that is separating many migrant families at the border.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Drawing on an American history of cruelty, from the conquest of the Indians to the slave trade to the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II, activists in this city gathered on Thursday to voice outrage at what they see as the latest affront to American values by the Trump administration: splitting up migrant families at border crossings, and confining children in detention facilities.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Marches Across the U.S. Protest Separation of Migrant Families

2018-06-14.abstract: Political turmoil, slowing growth and the prospect of a trade war fail to deter Europe’s central bank from ending economic stimulus measures.
2018-06-14.snippet: Political turmoil, slowing growth and the prospect of a trade war fail to deter Europe’s central bank from ending economic stimulus measures.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: RIGA, Latvia — A trade war with the United States looms. Populists have taken power in Italy, posing a new threat to the euro. Growth is sluggish, and there is even talk of another banking crisis.
2018-06-14.headline_main: As Uncertainty Clouds Economy, Europe Pulls Back on Easy Money

2018-06-14.abstract: France’s leader doesn’t care for his “president of the rich” label. The new china he ordered for the Élysée Palace may not help.
2018-06-14.snippet: France’s leader doesn’t care for his “president of the rich” label. The new china he ordered for the Élysée Palace may not help.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French president’s fondness for the gilt-edged aspects of his job — the fancy backdrops in chateaus, his big makeup bills, the proximity to the wealthy — is no longer a secret to his countrymen.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Let Them Eat on Fancy Plates: Emmanuel Macron’s New China

2018-06-14.abstract: Al Manaar became the center of relief efforts when a fire killed more than 70 people. Now, it is quieter ahead of what will be a somber celebration to mark the end of Ramadan.
2018-06-14.snippet: Al Manaar became the center of relief efforts when a fire killed more than 70 people. Now, it is quieter ahead of what will be a somber celebration to mark the end of Ramadan.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Abdurahman Sayed doesn’t know where he got the energy. Last year during Ramadan, the busiest time of the year for Muslims, Mr. Sayed, the director of Al Manaar mosque in West London, found himself thrust into a crisis that went on for weeks.
2018-06-14.headline_main: For Mosque at Heart of Grenfell Tragedy, a Bittersweet Anniversary

2018-06-14.abstract: Lt. Gov. Casey Cagle, the leading Republican in the race, profited off the sale of a high-rise apartment he purchased from a longtime lobbyist.
2018-06-14.snippet: Lt. Gov. Casey Cagle, the leading Republican in the race, profited off the sale of a high-rise apartment he purchased from a longtime lobbyist.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The leading Republican candidate in Georgia’s high-profile governor’s race, Lt. Gov. Casey Cagle, bought a condominium in downtown Atlanta 10 years ago from a State Capitol lobbyist, seemingly at a discount, a New York Times investigation has found.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Candidate for Georgia Governor Bought Condo From Lobbyist

2018-06-14.abstract: A beautiful, historic city, Seville is known for its cathedral, palace and, of course, Holy Week. Whenever you plan to visit, these essentials will help you make the most of your trip.
2018-06-14.snippet: A beautiful, historic city, Seville is known for its cathedral, palace and, of course, Holy Week. Whenever you plan to visit, these essentials will help you make the most of your trip.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: We asked Susanne Fowler, author of our guide to Seville, to name a few items she was glad to have on her last visit — or wished she had packed. Then we turned to Ria Misra, an editor at Wirecutter, for the best products to fill those needs as well as her expert suggestions. Here are their picks.
2018-06-14.headline_main: What to Pack for a Trip to Seville

2018-06-14.abstract: The artist conjures a surreal show set for the emerging fashion designer Charles Jeffrey.
2018-06-14.snippet: The artist conjures a surreal show set for the emerging fashion designer Charles Jeffrey.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: The artist conjures a surreal show set for the emerging fashion designer Charles Jeffrey.
2018-06-14.headline_main: In the Studio With the Set Designer Gary Card

2018-06-14.abstract: In his East London studio, Gary Card brings to life colorful creative projects with collaborators including Charles Jeffrey and FKA Twigs.
2018-06-14.snippet: In his East London studio, Gary Card brings to life colorful creative projects with collaborators including Charles Jeffrey and FKA Twigs.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: In recent years, the artist and set designer Gary Card has worked on large-scale installations for Nike, creative directed album artwork for artists such as Paul McCartney and FKA Twigs, and contributed to campaigns for Balenciaga, Hermès and Comme des Garçons. But some of his most innovative work comes from teaming up with emerging designers. One of his most buzzed-about collaborations is with the Scottish designer Charles Jeffrey, 27, whose Loverboy label is a riot of color, print and queerness — and a highlight of London Fashion Week Men’s.
2018-06-14.headline_main: The Artist Making Otherworldly Sets for London’s Emerging Designers

2018-06-14.abstract: The report faulted the former F.B.I. director James B. Comey for his decision making during the inquiry.
2018-06-14.snippet: The report faulted the former F.B.I. director James B. Comey for his decision making during the inquiry.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: A much-anticipated inspector general’s report about the F.B.I.’s handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton released on Thursday found that the former director James B. Comey was “insubordinate,” but it did not challenge the decision not to charge Mrs. Clinton and did not conclude that bias influenced that choice.
2018-06-14.headline_main: The Report on the F.B.I.’s Clinton Investigation Is 500 Pages. Our Experts Broke It Down.

2018-06-14.abstract: Watch these dancers, and join one of New York City’s biggest salsa parties.
2018-06-14.snippet: Watch these dancers, and join one of New York City’s biggest salsa parties.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Hidden from the world four floors below, a sweaty sea of partygoers  — all twisting, turning and swiveling — transform the Dancesport ballroom studio into one of the city’s largest salsa parties. Walk along 34th Street on a Sunday evening and you may catch a hint of the dueling trumpets and insistent rhythms swirling in the air.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Watch These Captivating Salsa Dancers, and Try Not to Break a Sweat

2018-06-14.abstract: Heimir Hallgrimsson is a laid-back leader and sometime dentist who sees success for Iceland’s national team as a continuing journey unconnected to its 2018 World Cup finish.
2018-06-14.snippet: Heimir Hallgrimsson is a laid-back leader and sometime dentist who sees success for Iceland’s national team as a continuing journey unconnected to its 2018 World Cup finish.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — As the coach of the most successful national soccer team in Icelandic history, Heimir Hallgrimsson has had to make some sacrifices. This year, for instance, he was abroad with the team and could not dress up as his favorite mythological character, Gryla the child-snatching troll, at the Christmas party in Heimaey, his hometown.
2018-06-14.headline_main: With a Coach Who Pulls Teeth to Relax, Iceland Becomes a Contender

2018-06-14.abstract: The judge’s decision that approved the new company barely touched on the law’s concern about concentration of economic power.
2018-06-14.snippet: The judge’s decision that approved the new company barely touched on the law’s concern about concentration of economic power.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: When Congress enacted the Anti-Merger Act of 1950, the law by which American courts still adjudge corporate mergers, it did so with the repeatedly stated goal of fighting excessive economic concentration. The “dominant” concern, as the Supreme Court wrote in a 1962 merger case that analyzed the law, was about “a rising tide of economic concentration in the American economy.” At the time, the court explained, a wave of corporate consolidation posed the threat of an “accelerated concentration of economic power” and also a “threat to other values,” like the independence of smaller businesses and local control of industry. In particular Congress had said it intended the new law to stop a wave of mergers in its “incipiency.”
2018-06-14.headline_main: The Dangerous ‘Bigness’ of the AT&T-Time Warner Merger

2018-06-14.abstract: In texts to a colleague, the agent overseeing the Trump investigation repeatedly expressed anti-Trump political views.
2018-06-14.snippet: In texts to a colleague, the agent overseeing the Trump investigation repeatedly expressed anti-Trump political views.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — New texts released Thursday by the Justice Department’s inspector general show that the F.B.I. agent overseeing the investigation into President Trump’s campaign pledged to stop Mr. Trump from becoming president.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Top Agent Said F.B.I. Would Stop Trump From Becoming President

Otting, during hearings before the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday, a day after he answered a question about the existence of lending or housing discrimination by saying he had never personally “observed” it.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Bank Regulator, on the Defensive, Endorses an Obama-Era Approach to Fight Discrimination

2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: The developers offered $54 million for air rights, in exchange for building a pair of tall towers next door, in what seemed like a deal too good to refuse. But on Thursday, the board of the Seward Park Cooperative on the Lower East Side said that the deal had failed to win approval from residents, in what some shareholders said was a symbolic message about overdevelopment.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Offered $54 Million for Air Rights, Co-op Says ‘No Thanks’

2018-06-14.snippet: Utilities say they must be shielded from liability or the electric grid will suffer. Critics say that puts the burden on ratepayers, not investors.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: FALLBROOK, Calif. — After flames rolled over the hills north of San Diego and engulfed vineyards, avocado groves and neighborhoods, hundreds in this area were left with only the charred remains of homes and businesses. For many, that moment in 2007 was the beginning of a long struggle to rebuild — if they did at all — and recover their financial losses.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Power Companies’ Mistakes Can Cost Billions. Who Should Pay?

2018-06-14.abstract: The White House and prominent Republicans in Congress cited a 1997 court settlement to justify separating migrant children from parents who illegally enter the United States. But the settlement did not require the government to break up families, and the practice has spurred protests against the Trump administration, a rebuke from the United Nations and a court challenge.
2018-06-14.snippet: The White House and prominent Republicans in Congress cited a 1997 court settlement to justify separating migrant children from parents who illegally enter the United States. But the settlement did not require the government to break up families, ...
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: — Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, to reporters on Thursday.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Republicans Misplace Blame for Splitting Families at the Border

2018-06-14.abstract: The E.P.A. chief is expected to submit to President Trump on Friday a proposal to cut a major Obama-era clean-water plan.
2018-06-14.snippet: The E.P.A. chief is expected to submit to President Trump on Friday a proposal to cut a major Obama-era clean-water plan.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, is expected on Friday to send President Trump a detailed legal proposal to dramatically scale back an Obama-era regulation on water pollution, according to a senior E.P.A. official familiar with the plan. It is widely expected to be one of his agency’s most significant regulatory rollback efforts.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Scott Pruitt, Under Fire, Plans to Initiate a Big Environmental Rollback

2018-06-14.abstract: Aleksandr Golovin scored a goal and helped create three others as Russia reassured its doubters by opening the 2018 World Cup with a 5-0 victory over Saudi Arabia.

2018-06-14.headline_main: For Russia, Five Goals and One Big Sigh of Relief

Comey clashed repeatedly with the White House over its interrogation and warrantless wiretapping programs, earning a reputation of fighting for his view of what was right no matter whom he angered.

Then, entranced by photography, he started taking pictures of — naturally — other musicians.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Photographing (and Singing) at a Brooklyn Karaoke Bar

2018-06-14.abstract: A philosophy to celebrate the infinite worth inherent in every human being.
2018-06-14.snippet: A philosophy to celebrate the infinite worth inherent in every human being.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: One of the lessons of a life in journalism is that people are always way more complicated than you think. We talk in shorthand about “Trump voters” or “social justice warriors,” but when you actually meet people they defy categories. Someone might be a Latina lesbian who loves the N.R.A. or a socialist Mormon cowboy from Arizona.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Personalism: The Philosophy We Need

2018-06-14.abstract: Hillary Clinton supporters saw the report on James Comey as proof the F.B.I. wronged her in 2016. “It’s disappointing and infuriating,” one ally said.
2018-06-14.snippet: Hillary Clinton supporters saw the report on James Comey as proof the F.B.I. wronged her in 2016. “It’s disappointing and infuriating,” one ally said.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Democrats have yearned for a moment of political exoneration ever since Hillary Clinton’s defeat in 2016. They have looked to Russian interference in the campaign, claims of bias in the media and allegations of Republican lawbreaking to explain an upset that few in the party foresaw.

2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: The new report from the Justice Department’s watchdog covers a lot of ground. It runs more than 500 pages and evaluates investigations that touch both President Trump and Hillary Clinton. As a result, some of the initial news coverage — which has to cram all of the big findings into a few paragraphs — can be a little difficult to follow.
2018-06-14.headline_main: The Report’s Real Message: Trump Is Lying

2018-06-14.abstract: Republican cruelty is a pre-existing condition.
2018-06-14.snippet: Republican cruelty is a pre-existing condition.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Polls suggest that the public considers health care the most important issue in the midterm elections. This immediately raises the question: Do voters understand what’s at stake? In particular, do they realize that if Republicans hold Congress, they will strip away protections for the 52 million Americans — more than a quarter of nonelderly adults — who have pre-existing conditions that, before passage of the Affordable Care Act, could have led insurers to deny them coverage?
2018-06-14.headline_main: G.O.P. to Americans With Health Problems: Drop Dead

2018-06-14.abstract: He and his allies are muddying the waters. It has nothing to do with the Mueller investigation.
2018-06-14.snippet: He and his allies are muddying the waters. It has nothing to do with the Mueller investigation.
2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: Within hours after the Department of Justice released a long-awaited report of the investigation into former F.B.I. Director James Comey’s handling of the Clinton email investigation, President Trump’s aides and allies were already using it to call into question a different case entirely: Robert Mueller’s investigation into possible links between the Trump campaign and Russia and obstruction of justice by the president.
2018-06-14.headline_main: Why Trump Is Wrong on the Comey Report

2018-06-14.abstract: Is the White House press secretary about to quit? If she does, here’s one way she’ll be remembered.

2018-06-14.abstract: Grifters ain’t gonna gift.

2018-06-14.lead_paragraph: It’s long been clear that Donald Trump’s family foundation, the Trump Foundation, is not a generous and ethical charity, but just another of his grifts. He branded it the way he brands his buildings, using his name to generate income that he then has used largely for his own benefit. In 2016, The Washington Post reported that many of Mr. Trump’s boasts about his charitable giving could not be verified. Those that could be were often gifts to himself.

2018-06-15.abstract: Reading to a child with cerebral palsy, the poet Craig Morgan Teicher discovers the many-layered pleasures of sharing an experience that is inherently private.
2018-06-15.snippet: Reading to a child with cerebral palsy, the poet Craig Morgan Teicher discovers the many-layered pleasures of sharing an experience that is inherently private.
2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: I love reading aloud to Cal. He’s 11, and it’s one of the warmest ways we have of spending intimate time together. We’ve been through all seven Harry Potter books, Roald Dahl’s “The Witches” and “Danny, the Champion of the World,” lots of Sherlock Holmes, several Narnia books and “The Hobbit.” Now we’re in the middle of the last book of the “Percy Jackson and the Olympians” series. Sometimes I think I’m enjoying all of them more than he is — they’re a welcome break from my grown-up literary reading. These middle-grade books are all about story, about characters one instantly loves and the phenomenal trials they endure and are changed by. It’s literature, but without the lengthy descriptions and pretensions to importance.
2018-06-15.headline_main: What a Father Learns by Reading With His Special-Needs Son

2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: AVDIIVKA, Ukraine — Headquarters for the 2nd Battalion of the 92nd Brigade of the Ukrainian Army is in a pummeled building that once housed the district road repair agency. War has left the building in even worse shape than the roads. At the entrances, sandbags and tires are stacked in fortification. Logs reinforce the basement ceiling against the shelling.

2018-06-15.abstract: A new exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London explores how the artist’s physical disabilities influenced her well-known image.
2018-06-15.snippet: A new exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London explores how the artist’s physical disabilities influenced her well-known image.
2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In late May, the high-ceiling textile-conservation department of the Victoria and Albert Museum was buzzing with activity. Curators fitted several full enagua skirts and square-cut embroidered huipil blouses — some bearing traces of paint and ink — onto mannequins. Alongside were heavy strings of Aztec beads, richly colored rebozo shawls and a starched lace headdress known as a resplandor — all ingredients of what would become the museum’s major summer exhibition: “Frida Kahlo: Making Her Self Up.”
2018-06-15.headline_main: The Real Story Behind Frida Kahlo’s Style

2018-06-15.abstract: For Mr. Johnson, if it’s Sunday, there’s probably a parade. And he will probably be dancing at it.
2018-06-15.snippet: For Mr. Johnson, if it’s Sunday, there’s probably a parade. And he will probably be dancing at it.
2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the Queens Pride parade and the Celebrate Israel parade fell on the same Sunday. What’s an ambitious New York politician — the first openly gay male, H.I.V.-positive City Council speaker — to do? “I alternate,” Corey Johnson said. “Last year I did Queens Pride and skipped Israel. This year I did Israel.” Since January, when Mr. Johnson went from representing Manhattan’s West Side to the entire city, the 36-year-old has sacrificed the traditional day of rest to an endless stream of public events, which he attends with “a wonderful group of rotating detectives,” he said. When not dancing in front of a parade float, he lives in a studio apartment in Chelsea with a cat named Mousse — because he’s “fat and sweet.”
2018-06-15.headline_main: How Corey Johnson, City Council Speaker, Spends His Sundays

2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: Every writer has their little tricks to uncork themselves when they’re feeling stuck. For many, it is alcohol. For some, it is the use and abuse of women. For me, it is procrastibaking. I watched this week’s episode twice, then made a peach cobbler. And yet, I still don’t know quite where to start — actually, now that I think about it, this was the peach cobbler of episodes! Sweet, comforting, with a distinct southern flavor and best served at the peak of the season. Here we go!
2018-06-15.headline_main: ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’ Season 10, Episode 12: An Elephant Noise

2018-06-15.abstract: Mary Heilmann and Larry Bell meet up ahead of simultaneous, decades-spanning exhibitions in Los Angeles.
2018-06-15.snippet: Mary Heilmann and Larry Bell meet up ahead of simultaneous, decades-spanning exhibitions in Los Angeles.
2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: The artists Mary Heilmann and Larry Bell, both 78, have a lot in common besides their age — sort of. Both were educated in California, though on different ends: Heilmann studied ceramics at Berkeley under Peter Voulkos, while Bell moved to Venice Beach out of Chouinard, where he showed, alongside friends like Ed Ruscha and Ed Moses, at the influential Ferus Gallery, co-founded by the curator Walter Hopps and run by Irving Blum. Both have been called Minimalists, though it plays out in their work in very different ways: Heilmann is best known for her vividly colored abstract paintings, Bell for his large glass cube installations. Both have a studio in the city and one in the country, though on opposite coasts: Heilmann works in New York and Bridgehampton, while Bell splits his time between Venice Beach and Taos, N.M. Both think a lot about Donald Judd, though only Bell ever met him.
2018-06-15.headline_main: Two American Art Icons Discuss the Old Days and Their New Shows

2018-06-15.abstract: From a new Printed Matter outpost to Codex’s $1 carts, a roundup of some nostalgic additions to the East Village.
2018-06-15.snippet: From a new Printed Matter outpost to Codex’s $1 carts, a roundup of some nostalgic additions to the East Village.
2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: The alternative art scene found a home in the East Village in the early 1980s. Artist-run collectives and unconventional exhibition spaces started to fill the empty storefronts; before long, however, the slept-on real estate became bank branches and chain coffee shops. But, as of late, the East Village has been reclaiming its reputation as a cultural haven with a series of new independent art bookstores. Here, a rundown of some nostalgic additions to the neighborhood.
2018-06-15.headline_main: The New York Neighborhood Where the Art Bookstore Is Alive and Well

2018-06-15.snippet: A New York Times reporter in Kashmir remembers Mr. Bukhari, who was killed on Thursday, as “a mentor and a friend who never failed us.”
2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: KREERI, Kashmir — This morning, I buried my friend and fellow journalist, Shujaat Bukhari, the editor of Rising Kashmir, a local daily that has never given up on its quest for peace in this war-torn place we call home. Amid family and friends, we lowered his body into the ground and bade him farewell forever, surrounded by vast apple orchards and lush green mountains in his ancestral village of Kreeri, in northern Kashmir.
2018-06-15.headline_main: Shujaat Bukhari Was a Fearless Journalist in Kashmir. He Was Also My Friend.

2018-06-15.snippet: For its first Pride program, the Joyce is pairing Madboots and Sean Dorsey Dance, whose documentary dance work explores the AIDS epidemic.
2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: The Joyce Theater is an Art Deco, neon landmark in the heart of Chelsea, long one of New York’s gay enclaves. Formerly a movie house (it opened in 1941), the Joyce was reborn as a dance theater in 1982, shortly after death moved into the neighborhood in the form of AIDS. In the years that followed, the Joyce presented both performances and memorials for artists lost to the disease.
2018-06-15.headline_main: For Pride Week at the Joyce Theater, a Painful Look Back

2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: Good morning. I had one of the great pizzas of my life in the No Name Pub on Big Pine Key, in Florida. It did not present as a good pizza in any way. It was big and doughy, a little underdone-overdone, salty-sweet with pineapple and ham, gooey with sauce and industrial cheese. But sometimes deliciousness is situational. I ate my pillow of pizza at the cool little bar there as mosquitoes outside raged in the heat, and years later I would defend its excellence in any court. Not all pizza needs to be thin and crisp.
2018-06-15.headline_main: What to Cook This Weekend

2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: In April I visited a crystal store in Minneapolis. Soft synthesized chimes played, the kind of sounds you get when you search for “spa music” on Pandora. I flipped through “The Crystal Bible” looking for a stone with healing properties for my sacral chakra — a center of spiritual power in the body. Next to me, a woman in a purple velvet newsboy hat examined fragrant bundles of palo santo wood, Spanish for “holy wood,” a serious look on her face.
2018-06-15.headline_main: Is Astrology Religion for Those of Us With No Religion?

If you like barbecued ribs, this could be a great summer for you. If you raise the pigs, you may be eating more barbecued beans.

2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: All Spain’s fans could do, after it was over, was applaud. There was no sense wallowing in disappointment, worrying about what it all might mean. Spain had victory snatched away at the last moment, denied a cathartic moment by its nearest neighbor, and yet there was no bitterness, no sorrow: only admiration, and awe. Sometimes, it is not the winning, but the taking part.

2018-06-15.abstract: The collection of downtown performers has been attracting listeners that don’t frequent traditional jazz sets, and bringing together like-minded artists.
2018-06-15.snippet: The collection of downtown performers has been attracting listeners that don’t frequent traditional jazz sets, and bringing together like-minded artists.
2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: The experimental jazz group Onyx Collective has a knack for attracting listeners that don’t frequent traditional jazz sets and collaborators whose approval can move the needle. In February, as three members of the New York band led by the 22-year-old saxophonist Isaiah Barr prepared to perform at the Eldridge Street Synagogue on the Lower East Side, the audience filled with young people dressed in high-end streetwear, and the downtown jazz mainstays Marc Ribot and Roy Nathanson joined onstage on guitar and alto sax. Before long, Mr. Nathanson and Mr. Barr’s horns were chasing each other down winding paths. The drummer Jamire Williams alternated between being a perfect metronome to playing offbeat so vigorously he nearly fell off his stool. At the end of the night, the audience rose to its feet slowly, staggered by the sound echoing through the Synagogue’s halls.
2018-06-15.headline_main: For Experimental Jazz Group Onyx Collective, the Only Rule Is ‘No Rules’

2018-06-15.abstract: Amid budget negotiations and a nationwide cultural tour, the prime minister of Portugal and the governor of New Jersey came to the Ironbound neighborhood to watch the World Cup.
2018-06-15.snippet: Amid budget negotiations and a nationwide cultural tour, the prime minister of Portugal and the governor of New Jersey came to the Ironbound neighborhood to watch the World Cup.
2018-06-15.lead_paragraph: NEWARK — It was barely past noon on Friday, and the Ironbound neighborhood in Newark was already a sea of red and white jerseys. Lines stretched down Ferry Street to get into Iberia, Mompou and other Portuguese restaurants. Red, green and gold garland draped across telephone poles. Portuguese songs blared from an open-air bar.
2018-06-15.headline_main: Murphy Visits Newark for the Portugal Match. His Guest? Portugal’s Prime Minister.

2018-06-16.abstract: For nearly 40 years, Mr. Reese shaped tastes, cultivated collectors and advised museums and libraries from his by-appointment-only store in New Haven.
2018-06-16.snippet: For nearly 40 years, Mr. Reese shaped tastes, cultivated collectors and advised museums and libraries from his by-appointment-only store in New Haven.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — William Reese, whose encyclopedic knowledge of historic American books and manuscripts made him a towering figure among rare-book sellers, died on June 4 at his childhood home in Havre de Grace, Md. He was 62.
2018-06-16.headline_main: William Reese, Leading Seller of Rare Books, Is Dead at 62

2018-06-16.abstract: He escaped war-torn Europe, had a lucky break in New York and then defined himself by remaining invisible behind the camera.
2018-06-16.snippet: He escaped war-torn Europe, had a lucky break in New York and then defined himself by remaining invisible behind the camera.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: Clemens Kalischer, who fled Germany in 1933 as the Nazis clinched power, survived imprisonment in France and escaped to the United States, where his haunting dockside images of other displaced persons arriving from Europe propelled his career as a noted photojournalist, died on June 9 at his home in Lenox, Mass. He was 97.
2018-06-16.headline_main: Clemens Kalischer, 97, Refugee Photographer of Humanity, Dies

2018-06-16.snippet: The attorney general’s invocation of a passage once used to defend slavery and oppose the American Revolution has prompted criticism from historians and theologians.

2018-06-16.snippet: As the president praised the North Korean leader, the Pentagon and South Korea moved toward canceling a large-scale and long-planned military exercise that was set for August.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump praised the strongman tactics of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, and dismissed American military exercises with South Korea as a waste of money on Friday, as his administration and allies scrambled to accommodate the president’s promises to Mr. Kim after their historic summit meeting this week.
2018-06-16.headline_main: Trump’s Promises to Kim Jong-un Leave U.S. and Allies Scrambling

2018-06-16.abstract: A new exhibit at Monticello tells her story through the eyes of Madison Hemings, a son of hers and Thomas Jefferson.
2018-06-16.snippet: A new exhibit at Monticello tells her story through the eyes of Madison Hemings, a son of hers and Thomas Jefferson.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: MONTICELLO, Va. — Sally Hemings takes center stage in Monticello on Saturday when the Thomas Jefferson Foundation opens an exhibit in a space where she is said to have lived for some time. Her story is told through the recollections of her son Madison Hemings, the third of four children she and Thomas Jefferson had who lived to adulthood. His memoir, published in an Ohio newspaper in 1873, gives vital information about the Hemings family genealogy, his mother’s life and the course of his own history.
2018-06-16.headline_main: Sally Hemings Takes Center Stage

2018-06-16.abstract: The dying columnist argued with rigor, not rancor; confidence, not certitude.
2018-06-16.snippet: The dying columnist argued with rigor, not rancor; confidence, not certitude.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: Charles Krauthammer, the Washington Post columnist, announced last week that he is stricken with terminal cancer and has only weeks to live. Since then, the tributes have poured forth, and rightly so. Charles taught generations of readers and fellow writers how to reason, persuade, live — and now how to die.
2018-06-16.headline_main: Charles Krauthammer’s Democratic Vocation

2018-06-16.abstract: From the meeting between President Trump and Kim Jong-un of North Korea to the release of a report highly critical of the former director of the F.B.I., a lot happened this week. PETERSBURG, Russia — The envelope might have been kept securely in her bag, but she still checked it every few minutes, just to make sure that the most precious of things was still there. It was something she had always wished for, but until now had always been denied.

2018-06-16.snippet: Bouillon Pigalle sticks to the spirit of the original bouillon concept: hearty, simple and inexpensive dishes served in a warm atmosphere.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: The scene is a familiar one in Paris: an expansive, brightly-lit dining room and servers decked head-to-toe in black and white, darting between tables with a balancing act of dishes in one hand and carafes of wine in another. Diners sit elbow-to-elbow in rows of ruby red leather banquettes or wooden bistro chairs, chatting over generous portions of beef bourguignon and escargots dressed in parsley butter.
2018-06-16.headline_main: At a Nostalgic Paris Restaurant, Food Takes a Back Seat to Fun

2018-06-16.abstract: As the kingdom prepares for its next evolution, Saudi Aramco is central. But a planned public listing leaves the company, and the country, at risk.
2018-06-16.snippet: As the kingdom prepares for its next evolution, Saudi Aramco is central. But a planned public listing leaves the company, and the country, at risk.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: RAS TANURA, Saudi Arabia — This port, on the calm blue waters of the Persian Gulf, operates with militarylike precision. Black- and red-hulled super oil tankers must ask for permission to load months in advance. Detailed records go back 30 years to trace any vessels that have broken the rules by dumping oil or using substandard equipment. High-tech radars constantly scan for potential troublemakers, like boats sent from Iran.
2018-06-16.headline_main: An Oil Giant Is Taking Big Steps. Saudi Arabia Can’t Afford for It to Slip.

2018-06-16.abstract: Many who trace their roots back to the enslaved community at Monticello are expected to attend the exhibit opening, along with some of Jefferson’s white descendants.
2018-06-16.snippet: Many who trace their roots back to the enslaved community at Monticello are expected to attend the exhibit opening, along with some of Jefferson’s white descendants.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Hundreds of people count themselves as descendants of Thomas Jefferson. And their numbers grew substantially after a DNA test in 1998 bolstered the case for Jefferson’s paternity of the children of Sally Hemings, his slave. That revelation spawned a feud between Hemings and Jefferson descendants over who would be allowed at sprawling Jefferson meetings. To this day, some white descendants of Jefferson deny that he had a sexual relationship with Hemings.
2018-06-16.headline_main: ‘She Was Part of This Family’: Jefferson Descendants Reflect on Sally Hemings Exhibit

2018-06-16.abstract: A trip through Dad’s heart and closet. Fannie Farmer gets an obituary. The sometimes blurry truth about Lasik. Time to tune up your summer reading list and more.
2018-06-16.snippet: A trip through Dad’s heart and closet. Fannie Farmer gets an obituary. The sometimes blurry truth about Lasik. Time to tune up your summer reading list and more.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Sunday is Dad’s day. If you’ve got a lawn, maybe mow it for him to say thanks for all the advice, manual labor (my dad moved me many times) and love. You could also just grab coffee and read some great journalism together.
2018-06-16.headline_main: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads

2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: When Steve Lickteig turned 18, he learned of a secret that threw his very identity into question. His best friends revealed to him that his mother and father, who he thought were his adopted parents, are in fact his biological grandparents. The woman who he thought was his eldest sister is actually his biological mother. And everyone in the small town he lived in knew about it.

2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: Q: I am a board member at an Upper West Side condo that has had issues with leaks. Repairing the problem will be expensive, possibly requiring a five-figure assessment for each apartment. I have been thinking about moving, but now I want to sell quickly to avoid paying the assessment and living through months of construction. Our board does not move quickly and any decision about the repairs is likely months away. The work could ultimately be cheaper than what is currently being proposed. What, if anything, am I required to disclose to potential buyers?

2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: ONE recent morning I happened across a scene of biblical violence. Flipping through Genesis, tracking down a quotation for a sermon, my eye caught on a chapter heading, “The Rape of Dinah.” I paused and turned the phrase in my mind. My heart began to ache. I took a breath, sat back in my chair, and read the story of Dinah.
2018-06-16.headline_main: The Bible’s #MeToo Problem

2018-06-16.abstract: The United States has the most fearsome cyberweaponry on the planet, but we won’t use it for fear of what will come next.
2018-06-16.snippet: The United States has the most fearsome cyberweaponry on the planet, but we won’t use it for fear of what will come next.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ask finance ministers and central bankers around the world about their worst nightmare and the answer is almost always the same: Sometime soon the North Koreans or the Russians will improve on the two huge cyberattacks they pulled off last year. One temporarily crippled the British health care system and the other devastated Ukraine before rippling across the world, disrupting shipping and shutting factories — a billion-dollar cyberattack the White House called “the most destructive and costly in history.”
2018-06-16.headline_main: Why Hackers Aren’t Afraid of Us

2018-06-16.abstract: A Pakistani writer recalls how, as a child, her father and his bookshelf introduced her to political humor and foretold her choice of career.
2018-06-16.snippet: A Pakistani writer recalls how, as a child, her father and his bookshelf introduced her to political humor and foretold her choice of career.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — When I was a child, my father earned a Ph.D in international relations at the University of Virginia, and I grew up surrounded by his books and papers everywhere in our small apartment overlooking the mountains surrounding Charlottesville. After he completed his studies, writing his thesis on international arms transfers to Iran, we moved back to Pakistan in 1977. My dad had already shipped his books home, so he could display them proudly on his bookshelves like hallowed objects.
2018-06-16.headline_main: Art Buchwald, My Father and Me

2018-06-16.abstract: Barack Obama, David Axelrod and Joel Benenson were all shaped by the same premature grief.
2018-06-16.snippet: Barack Obama, David Axelrod and Joel Benenson were all shaped by the same premature grief.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama’s parents separated when he was an infant, and he didn’t see his father again until he was 10. That was their last encounter. In place of his father’s touch, he had his father’s ghost. He titled his memoir “Dreams From My Father.”
2018-06-16.headline_main: Losing Fathers, Then Making History

2018-06-16.abstract: We need ways to control migration, but the separation of families shows us how not to do it.
2018-06-16.snippet: We need ways to control migration, but the separation of families shows us how not to do it.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: Let’s start with the easy part. The policy of separating children from their parents at the southern border, delivering them into a bureaucratic labyrinth while their fathers and mothers await trial or petition for asylum, is the wickedest thing the Trump administration has done so far — and you can tell exactly how wicked by observing how unwilling White House officials are to defend the policy on the merits.
2018-06-16.headline_main: The Lesser Cruelty on Immigration

2018-06-16.abstract: The baby needed us, but he wasn’t ours yet.
2018-06-16.snippet: The baby needed us, but he wasn’t ours yet.
2018-06-16.lead_paragraph: “Where’s the mother?” This is a question I’m often asked when I’m out with my son. I’m a gay dad. A New York gay dad with tattoos and pink hair. Around the world, in markets, restaurants and airports, strangers see our unconventional family and ask us about the seemingly missing mom. This question, although understandable, used to infuriate me.

2018-06-17.abstract: In “Twilight of the Gods,” Steven Hyden writes about what a generation of music gave to the culture — and whether any of it can last.
2018-06-17.snippet: In “Twilight of the Gods,” Steven Hyden writes about what a generation of music gave to the culture — and whether any of it can last.
2018-06-17.lead_paragraph: By the end of this year, Mick Jagger and Keith Richards will be a combined 150 years old. While it might be foolish to bet against the Rolling Stones touring in, say, 2025, there’s little doubt that the genre of classic rock — its practitioners, its fans, its clout — is in steep decline. To write “Twilight of the Gods,” Steven Hyden, who was born in the 1970s, spent time immersing himself in the music he loves. He listened to albums, attended concerts, read canonical books on the subject and generally mused on questions like: “Why is classic rock a lifestyle as much as a form of music? Where did these traditions come from, and how did they become so ingrained? And when did all that mythology come undone, sending classic rock from the cultural penthouse to the funeral parlor?” Below, Mr. Hyden talks about how the Who helped to inspire the book, the connection between music and mortality, and more.
2018-06-17.headline_main: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Drafting a Eulogy for Classic Rock

So full credit to Beyoncé and Jay-Z — known, in tandem, as the Carters — for extending their cone of silence all the way to the City of Light. Not only did the first couple of American pop music impose their standard omertà on the songwriters, musicians, producers and technicians who helped them complete their new album “Everything Is Love”; they also got the mandarins of Paris’s largest museum to keep mum about their first single, whose video was shot in the galleries and the exterior plaza of the Musée du Louvre.

2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dele Alli’s first memory of England at a World Cup is not of a goal or of a game. He cannot even place it to a specific tournament, not exactly. His best guess is 2006, when he would have just turned 10, but he cannot say for certain that it was not a couple of years earlier, at the European Championships of 2004. Both would fit the time frame: old enough to remember the outline, young enough to forget the detail.

2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: The art world, where the word contemporary gets thrown around as a kind of currency, is not known for its longevity. Artists, galleries, curators and even longstanding institutions tend to come and go without much ceremony, especially in New York, a city known for devouring its history and routinely replacing it with something newer and more expensive. Here, T looks at a few art-world survivors who have managed to stay relevant amid endless change.
2018-06-18.headline_main: The Stories Behind 5 New York Art Scene Legends

2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: It was Saturday night in Athens, and I was surrounded by dozens of young Greeks on the packed veranda of Six d.o.g.s., a cafe-bar and arts space that runs the length of an alleyway in the Monastiraki neighborhood. It was the 10-year anniversary party for Laternative, a local radio show launched in the wake of the country’s debt crisis, and people spilled into the gallery space, gathered under light-strung trees in the back garden and in the club area where the first of several bands was about to play.
2018-06-18.headline_main: Athens, Rising

2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: Political commentators and strategists write with some awe of President Trump’s outrageous, gutsy strategy of ginning up his base with one more attack on black athletes, one more crackdown on Central American mothers and children on the Mexican border, one more assault on Obamacare, one more tariff on imports. They think Mr. Trump’s drumbeat is intensifying loyalty and fervor among Republican partisans and that the Republican Party we used to know is “taking a nap somewhere,” as John Boehner, the former speaker of the House, put it.

2018-06-18.abstract: Anita L. Allen spoke to George Yancy about the humiliations and triumphs that she and her trailblazing colleagues faced in their careers.
2018-06-18.snippet: Anita L. Allen spoke to George Yancy about the humiliations and triumphs that she and her trailblazing colleagues faced in their careers.
2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: On July 1, Anita L. Allen will become the first black woman to be the president of the Eastern Division of the American Philosophical Association. She is the first African-American woman to hold both a Ph.D in philosophy and a law degree. In 2010, Dr. Allen was appointed by President Barack Obama to the Presidential Commission for the Study of Bioethical Issues, and in 2017 she was inducted into the National Academy of Medicine. She is the author of several books on privacy, law and ethics and is the vice provost for faculty and a professor of law and philosophy at the University of Pennsylvania. In this interview we discuss the obstacles faced by black women in philosophy, some of the painful experiences she endured in this predominantly white male profession and her vision of the future of philosophy.
2018-06-18.headline_main: The Pain and Promise of Black Women in Philosophy

I was 13 and watched the game on a small living-room television screen in Cairo, surrounded by my older cousins and their friends. We were a group of 20 Egyptians and one Dutch-Egyptian, whose loyalties were severely divided. It was Egypt’s first appearance in a World Cup in 56 years.

2018-06-18.abstract: A rise in armed groups around the world has forced organizations to reconsider how they promote respect for humanitarian law.
2018-06-18.snippet: A rise in armed groups around the world has forced organizations to reconsider how they promote respect for humanitarian law.
2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: Raiding among cattle-herding tribes is a traditional part of life in South Sudan, but in the past five years, the skirmishes have become more violent and unrestrained. Small armed bands that traditionally guarded their communities’ livestock have been drawn into bitter proxy battles between the country’s two largest tribes: the Dinka, who hold power in Juba, the national capital, and the Nuer. No longer limited to raiding each other’s villages and herds, these bands of well-armed tribal fighters have carried out massacres and atrocities, with women and children increasingly among the victims. The violence has worsened in both scale and frequency since 2013, according to South Sudanese who have witnessed the ravages of a civil war that started just two years after their country gained independence from Sudan.
2018-06-18.headline_main: There’s Been a Global Increase in Armed Groups. Can They Be Restrained?

2018-06-18.abstract: From a trip to New Orleans to a gallery opening and visit to her Connecticut country house, the artist shares snapshots of her friends and travels.
2018-06-18.snippet: From a trip to New Orleans to a gallery opening and visit to her Connecticut country house, the artist shares snapshots of her friends and travels.
2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: The artist Mickalene Thomas, best known for her vibrant paintings of women in lushly patterned living spaces, owns some 15 Polaroid cameras. She has seven or eight of the brand’s bellow-lensed Land Cameras in different colors. Her partner, the art consultant and collector Racquel Chevremont — who often opens the fridge in the couple’s Chelsea home in New York only to find packs of film — gifted her an SX-70 for a recent birthday. And when Thomas travels, she scours Salvation Army stores for other models to add to her collection.
2018-06-18.headline_main: Mickalene Thomas Photographs a Week in Her Life, in Polaroids

2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: Though Cupid appears in many guises it is safe to say he has seldom taken the form of a hard-boiled, deep-fried, sausage-wrapped cholesterol depth charge called a Scotch egg. Yet there, on their first real-time date in September 2015, at the Fiddler’s Hearth pub in South Bend, Ind., were Peter Buttigieg, 36, and Chasten Glezman, 28, and there, alongside a pint of Irish cider and an icy draft Guinness, not the usual pretzels or beer nuts but an order of Mr. Buttigieg’s favorite bar snack.
2018-06-18.headline_main: Pete Buttigieg Might Be President Someday. He’s Already Got the First Man.

2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: Despite his wife’s earlier attempt, it was Kanye West who finally broke the internet. Throughout his ascendance, the rapper and designer had fashioned himself as a mouthpiece for the black community, but then, one morning in April, West tweeted support for Donald Trump, posting a photo of himself in a Make America Great Again hat. (His previous political apex, after Hurricane Katrina, was claiming that George W. Bush didn’t care about black people.) He appeared on an hourlong episode of “TMZ Live” on May 1, on which he claimed, among other things, that slavery was a choice, an assertion that exploded in a shower of think pieces centered on the same question: What do we do with him?
2018-06-18.headline_main: How ‘Desus & Mero’ Conquered Late Night

2018-06-18.abstract: The painter and sculptor Glenn Ligon talks about a drawing by the conceptual artist Adrian Piper that has influenced his own work.
2018-06-18.snippet: The painter and sculptor Glenn Ligon talks about a drawing by the conceptual artist Adrian Piper that has influenced his own work.
2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: As part of a new video series for T, the painter and sculptor Glenn Ligon talks about an artwork that has been particularly important to him: “Self Portrait Exaggerating my Negroid Features” (1981) by Adrian Piper. Ligon first encountered Piper’s work in 1980, but it wasn’t until two decades later, at her New Museum retrospective, that he came face-to-face with the small pencil drawing. The portrait is as important as the language in its title, also written across the bottom of the piece, Ligon explains. “It makes us think about how what we think of as a self portrait is actually a portrait of the society that we live in,” he says.
2018-06-18.headline_main: What Kind of Art Does an Artist Like?

They also have no problem with commitment. The fellow (that’s an approximation) I hooked up with has already made a date with me when the visitors from another galaxy swing by here again, in 300 years.

2018-06-18.abstract: In his collection “Not Here,” the poet Hieu Minh Nguyen makes art from his memories of racism and abuse.
2018-06-18.snippet: In his collection “Not Here,” the poet Hieu Minh Nguyen makes art from his memories of racism and abuse.
2018-06-18.lead_paragraph: Hieu Minh Nguyen begins his concise and unsettling second book of poems with an apology, or an accusation: “It seems important to mention all the things / that went wrong.” And so many things have gone wrong, in Nguyen’s past and in the history of his family. His mother, who came to America from Vietnam, could not prevent his father, also Vietnamese, from abusing them both, emotionally and physically. As a child, he also faced racial hatred: “Boys … chucked rocks at our heads.” The young poet ran away from home. A grade school teacher repeatedly “molested” him, “my naked shape molting green in her hands. … She would find me at Champ’s playground. Even in the summer.” His best friend (whom she did not molest) died very young.
2018-06-18.headline_main: A Hard Childhood Compressed Into Poetry, With Concision and Heat

2018-06-19.lead_paragraph: LeRoy W. Henderson Jr. likes to capture life in passing, turning the street into his open-air studio. For more than four decades, the African-American photographer has traveled up and down the East Coast, stopping alongside rural roads in his native Virginia, at rallies on the National Mall and on bustling New York City street corners. Mr. Henderson has dedicated himself to showing the range of experiences of ordinary people, where the everyday is frozen in black-and-white, as the dramas of race, religion, social change and a day’s work play out in the frames.

2018-06-19.abstract: Some old houses come with ghosts, but when Betty Gilpin of “GLOW” started wrestling with renovations, she encountered a monster. A very familiar one.
2018-06-19.snippet: Some old houses come with ghosts, but when Betty Gilpin of “GLOW” started wrestling with renovations, she encountered a monster. A very familiar one.
2018-06-19.lead_paragraph: After the reality set in that only Versailles mafia oligarchs could afford Brooklyn real estate, my husband and I began to browse north for our dream weekend escape cabin. For the first few years after college, my acting career had been mostly Off Broadway theater, so my bank account consisted of four hugs and a cough drop. Still, we scoured Zillow together. My husband was raised by apocalypse-ready-Vermont-angel-people, and assured me he could turn any haunted tornado shack into a Nancy Meyers-worthy celebrity rehab center while I valiantly napped. Or at least that’s how my brain filtered the words, “We would do the work ourselves.”
2018-06-19.headline_main: Betty Gilpin: The First Time I Bought a Crumbling 1834 Farmhouse

2018-06-19.snippet: Investors are worried that worsening relations between the world’s two biggest economies will affect global growth.

2018-06-19.abstract: A selection of recent audiobooks; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2018-06-19.snippet: A selection of recent audiobooks; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2018-06-19.lead_paragraph: GOOD NIGHT STORIES FOR REBEL GIRLS By Francesca Cavallo and Elena Favilli. Read by a cast that includes Alicia Keys, Ashley Judd and Esperanza Spalding. (Listening Library.) The 100 stories told here about women scientists, chefs, jazz singers and boxers (among many others) are meant to inspire young girls. THE PATH TO PRIDE By Lance Bass and Nikki Levy. (Audible.) Recorded live and in honor of Pride Month, Bass and others recount their stories about coming out. HOW NOT TO GET SHOT By D. L. Hughley and Doug Moe. Read by Hughley. (HarperAudio.) One of the original “Kings of Comedy,” Hughley interprets the advice he says black people have been receiving from white people for the last four centuries (ever since “I suggest you pick the cotton if you don’t like getting whipped”). A satirical but apt addition to the culture’s fraught conversation about race. THE HIGH SEASON By Judy Blundell. Read by Julia Whelan. (Random House Audio.) Blundell tells the story of a summer in the Hamptons, with the rich and beautiful seen through the eyes of a local. HAS ANYONE SEEN THE PRESIDENT? By Michael Lewis. Read by the author. (S&S Audio.) In this audiobook original (which first appeared as an article in Bloomberg Businessweek) Lewis reports on how the nation’s capital has changed in the age of Trump.
2018-06-19.headline_main: New & Noteworthy

2018-06-19.abstract: Can even a single header in soccer affect a child’s cognitive abilities?
2018-06-19.snippet: Can even a single header in soccer affect a child’s cognitive abilities?
2018-06-19.lead_paragraph: The question of whether young children should use their heads on the soccer field has been a contentious one in recent years. In 2015, U.S. Youth Soccer, the organization that oversees most of the country’s leagues for children and teenagers, announced a ban on heading in games and practices by participants younger than 11, citing concerns that the play might contribute to concussions. In response, some soccer authorities pointed out that young players would be late to learn an essential soccer skill and that concussions from heading are rare in that age group regardless. Now a study presented last month at the annual convention of the American College of Sports Medicine may help quell doubts about the current regulations, which went into effect in 2016.
2018-06-19.headline_main: Heading the Soccer Ball May Be Bad for Young Brains

2018-06-19.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how far a teacher should go to help a student with personal difficulties, and more.
2018-06-19.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how far a teacher should go to help a student with personal difficulties, and more.
2018-06-19.lead_paragraph: I’m a professor at a state university. A few years ago, I had a situation with a student that still troubles me. I asked the young woman to see me in my office to discuss her absences from class and her poor performance. She was subdued during the session and said she would do better. But as she was leaving, she turned and said, “Professor, could I close the door and tell you something?”
2018-06-19.headline_main: Can a Professor Pay for a Student’s Counseling?

2018-06-19.abstract: The ideal solution for a dessert with snap.
2018-06-19.snippet: The ideal solution for a dessert with snap.
2018-06-19.lead_paragraph: Last month, when I returned from a trip to China, I knew for sure that it would take me about 12 days to recover from having spent time in a place that was 12 hours ahead of home in New York. I resigned myself to a dozen mornings of waking up before dawn and just as many afternoons of finding myself fuzzy-headed at 4 and ready for bed soon after. What I didn’t anticipate were the fierce cravings that struck at all hours. Throughout the days and into some nights, I wanted both what I loved in China and what I missed while I was there. I dreamed of congee drizzled with vinegar, soup dumplings, slurpable noodles, tofu so fragile it wriggled off a spoon. But what I yearned for most was what I’d had least, sweets with crunch — lots of crunch, full-on crunch — a texture that hardly turned up in Shanghainese cooking.
2018-06-19.headline_main: Nothing Satisfies the Need for Crunch Like Biscotti

2018-06-19.abstract: Rosalynn Carter, Hillary Clinton, Laura Bush and Michelle Obama have joined a chorus of criticism aimed at the Trump administration’s zero tolerance policy.
2018-06-19.snippet: Rosalynn Carter, Hillary Clinton, Laura Bush and Michelle Obama have joined a chorus of criticism aimed at the Trump administration’s zero tolerance policy.
2018-06-19.lead_paragraph: In the weeks since the Trump administration instituted a zero tolerance policy that seeks to criminally prosecute anyone who crosses the border unlawfully and effectively causes children to be separated from their families, criticism has poured in from advocacy groups, lawmakers on both sides of the aisle and a host of political luminaries who are no longer in office.
2018-06-19.headline_main: The 4 Former First Ladies Condemn Trump’s Border Policy

2018-06-19.abstract: It’s the one category broad enough to make tiny mistakes sound like grave errors, and terrible violations sound like simple misunderstandings.
2018-06-19.snippet: It’s the one category broad enough to make tiny mistakes sound like grave errors, and terrible violations sound like simple misunderstandings.
2018-06-19.lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, “inappropriate” described things that were “not done,” like wearing white after Labor Day or congratulating the bride. It applied to minor transgressions against codes of social behavior, formules de politesse. These days, though, it’s an alarm. To hear it used in connection with your name is no doubt to imagine the heart-stopping worst: revelations of shameful behavior, firings and resignations, public loathing and perp walks.
2018-06-19.headline_main: ‘Inappropriate’ Behavior Could Mean a Faux Pas — Or a Crime

2018-06-19.abstract: Across the country, time-limiting laws prevent scores of sexual assault cases from being prosecuted, in spite of persuasive evidence or a confession.
2018-06-19.snippet: Across the country, time-limiting laws prevent scores of sexual assault cases from being prosecuted, in spite of persuasive evidence or a confession.
2018-06-19.lead_paragraph: Around 1 a.m. on a Saturday in 1993, a man sneaked into Donna and John Palomba’s house in Waterbury, Conn. John was away for a long weekend, and Donna and her two young children were asleep when she awoke to the sound of heavy footsteps. She remembers seeing a masked man and screaming. An instant later, he was on her, threatening to hurt her if she didn’t comply. He covered her head with a pillowcase, wrapped nylon stockings around her mouth and eyes, bound her hands behind her back, cut open her underpants and raped her. Right before he fled, she recalls him saying: “If you call the pigs, I’ll come back and kill you.”
2018-06-19.headline_main: Should Statutes of Limitations for Rape Be Abolished?
