2018-06-27.abstract: The conceptual artist’s life and work push against the boundaries of race and identity in America.
2018-06-27.snippet: The conceptual artist’s life and work push against the boundaries of race and identity in America.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Adrian Piper, the conceptual artist and analytic philosopher, is almost as well known for what she has stopped doing as for what she has done. By 1985, she had given up alcohol, meat and sex. In 2005, she took a leave of absence from her job at Wellesley, sold her home on Cape Cod and shipped all of her belongings to Germany. On a lecture tour in the United States the next year, she discovered a mark on her plane ticket that suggested, to her, that she’d been placed on a watch list; she has not set foot in America since. Then, in 2012, on her 64th birthday, she “retired from being black.” She did this by uploading a digitally altered self-portrait to her website, in which she had darkened her skin — normally café très-au-lait — to the color of elephant hide. It was accompanied by a news bulletin announcing her retirement. The pithy text superimposed at the bottom of the photo elaborated: “Henceforth, my new racial designation will be neither black nor white but rather 6.25% grey, honoring my 1/16th African heritage,” she wrote. “Please join me in celebrating this exciting new adventure in pointless administrative precision and futile institutional control!” (Through extensive genealogical work, she later determined that her African heritage is closer to one-eighth.)
2018-06-27.headline_main: Adrian Piper’s Show at MoMA is the Largest Ever for a Living Artist. Why Hasn’t She Seen It?

2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The Frugal Traveler column has been around for 25 years. We got all five of the columnists together (virtually, that is) to discuss how the column has changed, what lessons they learned, and much more. Our current columnist, Lucas Peterson, hosted.
2018-06-27.headline_main: The Frugal Five

2018-06-27.abstract: Our 52 Places Traveler has spent the past five months on the road figuring out how to answer that question. Here are her most important takeaways on packing and prepping for long-term solo travel.
2018-06-27.snippet: Our 52 Places Traveler has spent the past five months on the road figuring out how to answer that question. Here are her most important takeaways on packing and prepping for long-term solo travel.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: You know those paisley Vera Bradley duffels beloved by sorority sisters and grandmas nationwide? I dragged one with me for the first four legs of my impossible, wonderful 52 Places trip because it was the only luggage I owned that fit all the things I thought I needed. It went home just before I left the United States, which made up the first few legs of my trip, along with some 20 pounds of clothes, according to my luggage scale. (I eventually ditched that, too.)
2018-06-27.headline_main: How Do You Pack for a Yearlong Trip?

2018-06-27.abstract: At Shipwrecked in Brooklyn, visitors can play 18 different holes in themed rooms evoking jungles, oceans and even the Coney Island boardwalk.
2018-06-27.snippet: At Shipwrecked in Brooklyn, visitors can play 18 different holes in themed rooms evoking jungles, oceans and even the Coney Island boardwalk.

2018-06-27.abstract: It was a night of rebellious Democrats, who backed progressive insurgents, and loyal Republicans, who helped incumbents backed by President Trump persevere.
2018-06-27.snippet: It was a night of rebellious Democrats, who backed progressive insurgents, and loyal Republicans, who helped incumbents backed by President Trump persevere.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: It was a night of rebellion among Democrats and loyalty for Republicans: Liberal activists upended the Democratic establishment in multiple primary races on Tuesday, while Republican voters backed candidates anointed by President Trump. The night broke the pattern of the last few years, when Republicans often challenged their leaders and Democrats usually fell in line.
2018-06-27.headline_main: 4 Takeaways From Tuesday’s Primary Elections

2018-06-27.abstract: In “How to Write an Autobiographical Novel,” a new essay collection, the author of “The Queen of the Night” argues that writing fiction involves allowing yourself to become someone else.
2018-06-27.snippet: In “How to Write an Autobiographical Novel,” a new essay collection, the author of “The Queen of the Night” argues that writing fiction involves allowing yourself to become someone else.

2018-06-27.headline_main: Writing as Drag: Alexander Chee’s Essays Consider the Novelist’s Craft

2018-06-27.abstract: Journals have long been a way for The Times’s foreign correspondents to bring readers with them as they explore a distant land. But they have needed a reboot, our international editor writes.
2018-06-27.snippet: Journals have long been a way for The Times’s foreign correspondents to bring readers with them as they explore a distant land. But they have needed a reboot, our international editor writes.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: For at least three decades, The New York Times’s international report included a feature called a Journal. The idea was to add variety to coverage generally focused on daily, often crisis-driven, news. The Journal was a place for our correspondents to bring readers with them to a fun or interesting spot in the world. It was a chance to write with voice and style.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Our International Report Becomes a Bit More Modern

2018-06-27.abstract: New satellite data reveals that the world’s tropical forests lost roughly 39 million acres of trees last year — an area the size of Bangladesh.
2018-06-27.snippet: New satellite data reveals that the world’s tropical forests lost roughly 39 million acres of trees last year — an area the size of Bangladesh.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: In Brazil, forest fires set by farmers and ranchers to clear land for agriculture raged out of control last year, wiping out more than 3 million acres of trees as a severe drought gripped the region. Those losses undermined Brazil’s recent efforts to protect its rain forests.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Tropical Forests Suffered Near-Record Tree Losses in 2017

2018-06-27.abstract: The soccer academy that produced Hirving Lozano, a star known as Chucky who scored a critical goal for Mexico at the World Cup, aims to ramp up the development of young players like him.
2018-06-27.snippet: The soccer academy that produced Hirving Lozano, a star known as Chucky who scored a critical goal for Mexico at the World Cup, aims to ramp up the development of young players like him.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: PACHUCA, Mexico — In the bottom floor of the dormitory at one of Mexico’s most successful soccer academies, more than two dozen middle-school-age boys gathered last week to watch intently as Croatia crushed Argentina in a World Cup game.
2018-06-27.headline_main: A Nightmare for Mexico’s Soccer Opponents: More Chuckys On the Way

2018-06-27.abstract: With seductive aromas of almonds, vanilla and lilies, the fruit’s kernel adds a delight that is simultaneously familiar and indescribable.
2018-06-27.snippet: With seductive aromas of almonds, vanilla and lilies, the fruit’s kernel adds a delight that is simultaneously familiar and indescribable.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Apricots are the most private fruit, loath to reveal their secrets. While other stone fruits grow tender on the surface as they ripen, apricots take an alternate path to maturity, softening from the inside out. I’ve given up on trying to tell whether they’re ripe by gently pressing on their skin, as I do with cherries, peaches and plums. I just rip one open at the seam, in search of juicy flesh that’s soft but not mealy.
2018-06-27.headline_main: How to Unlock the Secret Flavor Hidden at the Apricot’s Core

2018-06-27.abstract: With smartphones, everything digital has been managed through screens. Now that all of our visual capacity has been captured, the tech giants are starting to build a less eyes-only world.
2018-06-27.snippet: With smartphones, everything digital has been managed through screens. Now that all of our visual capacity has been captured, the tech giants are starting to build a less eyes-only world.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Smartphones were once the best thing to happen to the tech industry — and for a while, it seemed, to all of us, too. In the 11 years since the iPhone made its debut, smartphones have subsumed just about every other gadget and altered every business, from news to retail to taxis to television, ultimately reordering everything about how we understand media, politics and reality itself.
2018-06-27.headline_main: We Have Reached Peak Screen. Now Revolution Is in the Air.

2018-06-27.abstract: Paul Carluccio, 47, paints canvas rubbings of manhole covers on the streets and sidewalks of New York City.
2018-06-27.snippet: Paul Carluccio, 47, paints canvas rubbings of manhole covers on the streets and sidewalks of New York City.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: “I like painting outside — it keeps my overhead low,” said Paul Carluccio, kneeling on a sidewalk on Carmine Street in the West Village. “I don’t have a gallery — my studio is right here.”
2018-06-27.headline_main: Manhole Impressionist

2018-06-27.abstract: American soldiers and allies, on a military exercise in Poland and Lithuania, are ramping up to thwart Russian cyberattacks and information warfare.
2018-06-27.snippet: American soldiers and allies, on a military exercise in Poland and Lithuania, are ramping up to thwart Russian cyberattacks and information warfare.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: ORZYSZ, Poland — Soon after a United States Army convoy crossed Poland’s border into Lithuania during a major military exercise this month, two very strange things happened.

2018-06-27.abstract: He quietly ruled the national-security state under President Obama. Now he’s coming forward to rail against Trump — and to defend his own legacy.
2018-06-27.snippet: He quietly ruled the national-security state under President Obama. Now he’s coming forward to rail against Trump — and to defend his own legacy.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: On June 4, John Brennan, the former C.I.A. director, made the long drive from suburban Virginia to New Jersey. He had plans to dine with his brother and an old high school friend. The evening would be a respite from Brennan’s public feud with the president of the United States, whom Brennan unfailingly refers to as “Mr. Trump.” A few days before, Brennan wrote an op-ed calling Trump “a snake-oil salesman.” The paper’s editors tried to persuade Brennan to use the word “president,” but Brennan refused. “I said no, I’m not going to refer to him as ‘president,’ ” Brennan told me. “Because he doesn’t deserve that, in my mind. Yes, he won the most electoral votes. But I think he has demonstrated, over and over again, that he is unfit to carry out the responsibilities of that office.” Trump fired back at Brennan a few hours after the op-ed was published, tweeting out a quote from a former Secret Service agent who had appeared on “Fox & Friends.” Brennan was both a “liar” and “a liar about being a liar,” the guest said.
2018-06-27.headline_main: John Brennan, Former C.I.A. Spymaster, Steps Out of the Shadows

2018-06-27.abstract: Only in America, getaway drivers and lookouts can face the same penalty for a death as the actual killer. California is having second thoughts.
2018-06-27.snippet: Only in America, getaway drivers and lookouts can face the same penalty for a death as the actual killer. California is having second thoughts.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Late in the evening on Jan. 27, 2004, four teenagers broke into an elderly neighbor’s house in the Southern California town of Perris, looking for cash.
2018-06-27.headline_main: If He Didn’t Kill Anyone, Why Is It Murder?

2018-06-27.abstract: When the Indian Point power plant closes, the village may lose half its revenue. But that hasn’t caused an exodus, thanks to relatively affordable housing.
2018-06-27.snippet: When the Indian Point power plant closes, the village may lose half its revenue. But that hasn’t caused an exodus, thanks to relatively affordable housing.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The southern half of Buchanan, a tiny northern Westchester suburb on the Hudson River, is crisscrossed by leafy streets lined with well-tended homes. The northern half is another story: an industrial expanse that includes Con Edison switchyards, a gypsum manufacturing facility and Entergy’s Indian Point Energy Center, with its domed nuclear reactors set on 240 riverfront acres.

2018-06-27.snippet: Sympathy for the restaurateur, skepticism for incivility as a strategy.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: In almost every opinion on the restaurant that famously refused to serve Sarah Huckabee Sanders, there is a too-neat congruence between the moral argument and the meta-political argument. If you think it’s right and just and admirable to deprive a Trump administration mouthpiece of an evening out in polite society, you probably also think that this sort of direct action is the vital spark that the left needs to mobilize and defeat Trumpism outright.

2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: We’ve been here before: America had a “travel ban” crisis more than three and a half centuries ago, and it was resolved, pragmatically, with an appeal to the universal principle of religious freedom. That case should serve as a touchstone for those who are saddened and outraged by the Supreme Court’s decision to uphold President Trump’s ban on admitting people from selected mostly Muslim countries.

2018-06-27.abstract: Alan Seeger’s poetry described a war in which fighting was “the supreme experience,” a part of nature humans were destined to take part in.
2018-06-27.snippet: Alan Seeger’s poetry described a war in which fighting was “the supreme experience,” a part of nature humans were destined to take part in.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: June 21, 1916. Pvt. Alan Seeger, an American volunteer in the French Foreign Legion, encloses a poem with a letter to his godmother. Nine sentences and 14 lines: an update from a tiny, unidentified village to the rear of the Western Front, and a sonnet. The sentences in the letter are short, stilted, like the ones a parent might hear after asking her child how school was that day. “Fine hot summer weather. The big attacks will come soon now. . . . I am twenty-eight years old tomorrow.”
2018-06-27.headline_main: The Poet-Soldier Who Went to His Grave With a Romantic Vision of World War I

2018-06-27.abstract: A dozen boys and their soccer coach, trapped in a flooded cave complex since Saturday, are the focus of a huge rescue operation and the hopes of a watching country.

Teams of navy divers worked their way through submerged passageways in the flooded cavern. The vigil of family and friends outside echoed across Thailand on social media and television.
2018-06-27.headline_main: As Search for Thai Boys Lost in Cave Hits Day 5, a Nation Holds Its Breath

2018-06-27.abstract: Conventional wisdom dictates that you have to book a round-trip itinerary in order to get a great airfare. But shopping around for one-way fares might save you money.
2018-06-27.snippet: Conventional wisdom dictates that you have to book a round-trip itinerary in order to get a great airfare. But shopping around for one-way fares might save you money.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: If you want to find bargain airfares during peak holiday travel periods, particularly in the summer, you’ll need to be flexible and creative. For example, I frequently book one-way flight segments, even if it means using airports that weren’t in my original plans. In my travel world, a trip to Greece can veer off into Britain, Denmark or anywhere else that saves me money.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Sizing Up the Bargain Potential of One-Way Airfares

2018-06-27.abstract: This film, about brothers who work at a factory, is a mix of the bleak and the absurdist.
2018-06-27.snippet: This film, about brothers who work at a factory, is a mix of the bleak and the absurdist.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: “Winter Brothers” is a debut feature from a director with a background as a visual artist; for better and worse, it shows. Hlynur Palmason, born in Iceland but based in Copenhagen, shot the movie in and around a real-life limestone factory in Denmark, a location that allows Mr. Palmason and his sound designer, Lars Halvorsen, to give the film an extraordinary aural dimension. The clanks, drips and sirens of the workplace accumulate in a soundscape that suggests Björk crossed with “Stomp.” An electronic score by Toke Brorson Odin blends well into the industrial symphony.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Review: In ‘Winter Brothers,’ a Frosty Sibling Rivalry

2018-06-27.abstract: The cultural entrepreneur Bobbito Garcia directs this documentary about a familiar subject: himself.
2018-06-27.snippet: The cultural entrepreneur Bobbito Garcia directs this documentary about a familiar subject: himself.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Bobbito Garcia, the author, basketball maven, sneaker obsessive, D.J. and all-around culture entrepreneur, is one of the most personable documentary subjects I’ve encountered in quite some time. He’s a born anecdotalist with a lot of interesting friends. Whether he’s addressing the camera solo, or in the company of one of those friends — Rosie Perez is among the most prominent — he’s funny, likable, sympathetic.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Review: ‘Rock Rubber 45s’ Looks in the Mirror to Tell a Life Story

2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The year is 1816, and Thomas Jefferson, living in post-presidential splendor in Monticello, has been called on to give some advice. The state legislature of North Carolina has resolved to build a monument to George Washington that will have pride of place in the capitol building in Raleigh. Jefferson, who (with Benjamin Franklin) had overseen a similar statue for the Virginia capitol decades before, is asked who would be up to the task of sculpting the general in marble now.

(Frederick Law Olmsted Jr. was one of the community’s designers.) The house sits high on a hill across from the Baltimore Country Club and is about five miles northwest of downtown.

It was constructed in the early 1800s and expanded and restored between 1999 and 2008. The one-acre property also includes a 538-square-foot guesthouse, an outdoor kitchen and a 75-foot swimming pool.

2018-06-27.abstract: The Pritzker winners RCR are representing their region at a Venice Biennale whose official exhibition is limited to the pavilions of nation states.
2018-06-27.snippet: The Pritzker winners RCR are representing their region at a Venice Biennale whose official exhibition is limited to the pavilions of nation states.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: VENICE — The Pritzker Prize is considered architecture’s highest award. So it might come as a surprise that last year’s recipients, the three partners of RCR Arquitectes, presented their work at the Venice Architecture Biennale not as a centerpiece of the exhibition, but in an industrial space on its periphery.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Prizewinning Catalan Architects Are Happy at Biennale’s Margins

2018-06-27.abstract: The company had envisioned a fleet of solar-powered aircraft that would help bring more people online in remote parts of the world.
2018-06-27.snippet: The company had envisioned a fleet of solar-powered aircraft that would help bring more people online in remote parts of the world.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Facebook has made splashy announcements over the last four years about building a fleet of solar-powered drones, with wingspans bigger than a Boeing 737, beaming internet access to people around the world who can’t otherwise get online. (When you have as many users as Facebook, finding new ones requires some ingenuity.)
2018-06-27.headline_main: Facebook Halts Aquila, Its Internet Drone Project

2018-06-27.headline_main: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week

2018-06-27.abstract: The court ruled that government workers cannot be required to pay for collective bargaining, which could cost public unions tens of millions of dollars.
2018-06-27.snippet: The court ruled that government workers cannot be required to pay for collective bargaining, which could cost public unions tens of millions of dollars.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court dealt a major blow on Wednesday to organized labor. By a 5-to-4 vote, with the more conservative justices in the majority, the court ruled that government workers who choose not to join unions may not be required to help pay for collective bargaining.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Supreme Court Ruling Delivers a Sharp Blow to Labor Unions

2018-06-27.abstract: The gathering has worried some European allies, who fear it could overshadow a NATO summit meeting and President Trump’s visit to Britain in mid-July.
2018-06-27.snippet: The gathering has worried some European allies, who fear it could overshadow a NATO summit meeting and President Trump’s visit to Britain in mid-July.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump plans to meet President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia next month in a one-on-one summit meeting, a politically sensitive encounter that could exacerbate strains with NATO allies even if it eases tensions between the United States and Russia.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Trump and Putin Will Hold Summit Meeting, Officials Say

2018-06-27.abstract: The only solution for labor, after the Supreme Court decision in Janus, is militant, confrontational action by workers, with or without union support.
2018-06-27.snippet: The only solution for labor, after the Supreme Court decision in Janus, is militant, confrontational action by workers, with or without union support.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision in Janus v. American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which ruled that public sector unions may no longer require all the workers they represent to pay “agency fees,” is a wound to the labor movement that will bleed resources at a time when it’s already weak. Working Americans must now get radical to get heard. Even the lawyer representing the unions warned during oral arguments that when unions are denied agency fees, “they tend to become more militant, more confrontational.” The moment now necessitates it.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Workers Must Get Radical to Fight Back Against Janus

2018-06-27.abstract: The president of South Sudan and his former vice president signed a peace deal in a bid to end their country’s protracted civil war.
2018-06-27.snippet: The president of South Sudan and his former vice president signed a peace deal in a bid to end their country’s protracted civil war.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The president of South Sudan and his former vice president signed a peace deal on Wednesday in a bid to end their country’s protracted civil war.
2018-06-27.headline_main: A Peace Deal for South Sudan Is Signed. Will It Last?

2018-06-27.abstract: Divided House Republicans failed to pass legislation to protect the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers, fund a border wall and make significant changes to legal immigration.
2018-06-27.snippet: Divided House Republicans failed to pass legislation to protect the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers, fund a border wall and make significant changes to legal immigration.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House resoundingly rejected a far-reaching immigration overhaul on Wednesday, despite a last-minute plea from President Trump, as internal divisions in the Republican ranks continued to hobble legislative efforts to protect the young unauthorized immigrants known as Dreamers.
2018-06-27.headline_main: House Rejects Immigration Overhaul Despite Trump’s Late Plea

2018-06-27.abstract: The ruling could cost public-sector unions more than a million members. But the ones who stay could make labor more powerful.
2018-06-27.snippet: The ruling could cost public-sector unions more than a million members. But the ones who stay could make labor more powerful.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: With the Supreme Court striking down laws that require government workers to pay union fees, one thing is clear: Most public-sector unions in more than 20 states with such laws are going to get smaller and poorer in the coming years.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Labor Unions Will Be Smaller After Supreme Court Decision, but Maybe Not Weaker

2018-06-27.abstract: How a Times journalist sought to remedy the persistent lack of positive media representation of L.G.B.T. people of color in love.
2018-06-27.snippet: How a Times journalist sought to remedy the persistent lack of positive media representation of L.G.B.T. people of color in love.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Brown, Black, Queer and Invisible

2018-06-27.abstract: Tonight, make katsudon, curried tofu or our no-recipe recipe for hot sage and sausage over pasta.
2018-06-27.snippet: Tonight, make katsudon, curried tofu or our no-recipe recipe for hot sage and sausage over pasta.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Good morning. I was out West for a week, staying with friends in Tucson and not cooking at all, and that was a strange feeling after many months of cooking for family and writing about it every day. I kept thinking of things I wanted to make when I got home: shrimp tossed in sweet butter, to eat with toast; ribs cooked forever in a bath of hardwood smoke; clams on the half-shell, naked and salty and cold. It was a kind of reverie, without a recipe in sight.
2018-06-27.headline_main: What to Cook Right Now

2018-06-27.abstract: Timothée Chalamet and Steve Carell star as an addicted son and his father in “Beautiful Boy,” adapted from the real-life story of Nic and David Sheff.
2018-06-27.snippet: Timothée Chalamet and Steve Carell star as an addicted son and his father in “Beautiful Boy,” adapted from the real-life story of Nic and David Sheff.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Timothée Chalamet earned an Oscar nomination this year for his performance in “Call Me by Your Name” as a young gay man who has a heartwarming bond with his father. In “Beautiful Boy,” Mr. Chalamet plays a meth addict whose relationship with his dad (Steve Carell) might better be described as heart-rending.
2018-06-27.headline_main: It’s June. Here’s the Trailer for Your First Oscar 2019 Contender.

2018-06-27.abstract: Public employee unions have too much influence in some states. The Supreme Court’s ruling will take them down a peg.
2018-06-27.snippet: Public employee unions have too much influence in some states. The Supreme Court’s ruling will take them down a peg.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: In its 5-4 decision in Janus v. American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the Supreme Court on Wednesday declared unconstitutional laws that require public employees to pay “agency fees” to unions that they refuse to join. The court’s ruling, will not, as critics fear, deliver a “death blow” to unions. But it will restore to thousands of public employees the right to decide which political causes to support with their money.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Janus Decision Reins in Unions’ Political Power

2018-06-27.abstract: The more fit, the lower the risk of depression and death from heart disease.
2018-06-27.snippet: The more fit, the lower the risk of depression and death from heart disease.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Physical fitness in middle age is tied to a lower risk of later-life depression and death from cardiovascular disease, a new study reports.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Midlife Fitness May Protect Against Later Depression

2018-06-27.abstract: For one teenager who fled violence in El Salvador on his own in 2014, the days he spent in a Texas border detention center were some of the worst of his life. He tells us what it was like.

2018-06-27.abstract: Workers are already fighting in right-to-work states. The Supreme Court ruling doesn’t have to spell death.
2018-06-27.snippet: Workers are already fighting in right-to-work states. The Supreme Court ruling doesn’t have to spell death.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The day that organized labor has been dreading for several years is finally here. Janus v. American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees was decided by a 5-4 majority in favor of Mark Janus, who argued that he should not have to pay a fee to the union that represented employees at his workplace on First Amendment grounds. Justice Samuel Alito, for the majority, agreed, writing, “agency fees cannot be upheld on the ground that they promote an interest in ‘labor peace.’ ”
2018-06-27.headline_main: With Janus, the Court Deals Unions a Crushing Blow. Now What?

2018-06-27.abstract: Steve Lohr, a veteran New York Times reporter, reflects on how tech-free newsrooms used to be and how the progression to the internet has changed journalism.
2018-06-27.snippet: Steve Lohr, a veteran New York Times reporter, reflects on how tech-free newsrooms used to be and how the progression to the internet has changed journalism.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Steve Lohr, a technology reporter in New York, discussed the tech he’s using.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Now He Pulls Data Off the Web. In 1979, It Was Clips From the ‘Morgue.’

2018-06-27.snippet: The former Fox News executive, who was ousted for his handling of sexual harassment scandals at the network, met with President Trump in recent weeks for the post left open by Hope Hicks.

2018-06-27.snippet: The decision would require Disney, which already owns ESPN, to divest 22 regional sports networks.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice approved the Walt Disney Company’s $71 billion bid for the entertainment assets of 21st Century Fox on Wednesday, potentially complicating Comcast’s desire to make a rival offer for Rupert Murdoch’s entertainment empire.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Justice Dept. Approves Disney’s Purchase of Fox Assets

2018-06-27.abstract: The Flushing Remonstrance, a frayed petition from 1657 that pressed for religious freedom, will be shown through Monday at Federal Hall on Wall Street.
2018-06-27.snippet: The Flushing Remonstrance, a frayed petition from 1657 that pressed for religious freedom, will be shown through Monday at Federal Hall on Wall Street.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: If you think the Flushing Remonstrance is a homeowner’s complaint to a plumber, think again. The frayed petition from 1657 is one of the foundational documents of American freedom — and for the first time in three decades it is on display in Manhattan, through Monday at Federal Hall on Wall Street.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Document That Inspired Bill of Rights Goes on Display in Manhattan

2018-06-27.abstract: A 2-2 draw with Costa Rica was enough for Switzerland to advance to the next round. For Costa Rica, the team was happy to just finally score.
2018-06-27.snippet: A 2-2 draw with Costa Rica was enough for Switzerland to advance to the next round. For Costa Rica, the team was happy to just finally score.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: A 2-2 draw in Nizhny Novgorod on Wednesday gave both teams something they wanted. For Switzerland, it was the point it needed to qualify for the next round. For Costa Rica, it was two goals, after a Cup without any.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Switzerland Does Enough to Advance in World Cup

2018-06-27.abstract: Brazil, which advanced to the round of 16 to face Mexico, is a more balanced team this time around, defined as much by Coutinho’s table-setting as by Neymar’s finishing.
2018-06-27.snippet: Brazil, which advanced to the round of 16 to face Mexico, is a more balanced team this time around, defined as much by Coutinho’s table-setting as by Neymar’s finishing.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It was Philippe Coutinho’s birthday a few days before Brazil’s first game of this World Cup. To celebrate, his teammates gave him a cake. Or, rather, they gave him the ingredients for one.
2018-06-27.headline_main: All Eyes Are on Neymar, but It’s Coutinho Who Is Leading Brazil

2018-06-27.abstract: When children are too old to have full-time care but too young to be left to their own devices, working parents need a strategy.
2018-06-27.snippet: When children are too old to have full-time care but too young to be left to their own devices, working parents need a strategy.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: During the academic year, school serves as child care for many families. But come summer, many parents find themselves cobbling together a mix of camps, sports and educational programs with babysitters to fill the gaps — all of which can strain budgets and resources.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Parents, What’s Your Summer Game Plan?

2018-06-27.abstract: A first family of American football has embraced the world game. In fact, make that 11 of the past 12 World Cups for Clark Hunt.
2018-06-27.snippet: A first family of American football has embraced the world game. In fact, make that 11 of the past 12 World Cups for Clark Hunt.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — The World Cup attracts all kinds, even a scion of one of the most famous families in American football.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Clark Hunt Is an N.F.L. Owner. And He’s at the World Cup. Again.

2018-06-27.abstract: Pastora Asunción Gutierrez Reyes is an advocate for change in her traditional Zapotec community.
2018-06-27.snippet: Pastora Asunción Gutierrez Reyes is an advocate for change in her traditional Zapotec community.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: In the Zapotec village of Teotitlán del Valle, in Oaxaca State, Mexico, the rug-weaver Pastora Asunción Gutierrez Reyes, 46, graciously welcomes me into the open courtyard of her home. She is in the midst of pulverizing cochineal, a parasitic insect, to create a red dye. On an open fire nearby, pomegranate skins are simmering in a pot of water. All the dye recipes Gutierrez uses belong to her great-grandmother. The patterns and symbols that she weaves into colorful rugs are pre-Hispanic representations of the cycles of life and the natural world.
2018-06-27.headline_main: A Rug-Weaver Searching for Social Justice in Oaxaca

2018-06-27.abstract: The monthlong men’s wear season, with stops in Florence, Milan and Paris, may not be hanging together thematically. But in terms of moments, it has provided some doozies.
2018-06-27.snippet: The monthlong men’s wear season, with stops in Florence, Milan and Paris, may not be hanging together thematically. But in terms of moments, it has provided some doozies.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Back at the start of a cycle of men’s wear shows that began in Florence in early June, continued to Milan and Paris, and will end in New York in early July, I took part in “The Florence Experiment.” This site-specific project by the artist Carsten Höller and Stefano Mancuso, a scientist who studies plant intelligence, consists of two coiled and intersecting 65- foot chutes installed inside the courtyard of the Renaissance Palazzo Strozzi.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Staying in the (Fashion) Moment

2018-06-27.abstract: With two pieces performed on the High Line, the choreographer Alexandra Bachzetsis explores gender with surfaces in mind.
2018-06-27.snippet: With two pieces performed on the High Line, the choreographer Alexandra Bachzetsis explores gender with surfaces in mind.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: A latex dress. A man’s suit. A thick coat of red lipstick. In “PRIVATE: Wear a mask when you talk to me” and “Private Song,” the choreographer Alexandra Bachzetsis explores the idea of gender with surfaces in mind. If you want to transform into another look — male or female — simply wipe yourself clean and start over. And then, always, strike a pose.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Review: On the High Line, Striking Poses in Latex and Lipstick

2018-06-27.abstract: Mr. Brown, known for his drumming with Ambrose Akinmusire, Thundercat and others, is stepping into the spotlight with a new album, “Nyeusi.”
2018-06-27.snippet: Mr. Brown, known for his drumming with Ambrose Akinmusire, Thundercat and others, is stepping into the spotlight with a new album, “Nyeusi.”
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The drummer Justin Brown first arrived in New York almost 15 years ago, scholarship in hand, to attend Juilliard. He lasted at school for exactly one day.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Justin Brown Is a Monster on Drums. Now He’s a Bandleader, Too.

2018-06-27.abstract: The man, James A. Fields Jr., also faces local charges of first-degree murder in the death of a woman protesting a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va., last summer.
2018-06-27.snippet: The man, James A. Fields Jr., also faces local charges of first-degree murder in the death of a woman protesting a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va., last summer.

2018-06-27.abstract: His son Michael called him “a managerial genius,” but his abusive behavior alienated Michael, Janet and the rest of his children.

2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Joe Jackson, the domineering father and manager who molded his sons into the immensely popular Jackson 5 and helped launch his son Michael and his daughter Janet on explosive solo careers before alienating all of them because of his abusive behavior, has died in Las Vegas. He was 89.

2018-06-27.abstract: The Angel in “Angels in America” is supported by five shadows — at the sound of a whooshing exhale the puppeteers manipulate her wings while the dancers lift her into the air.

2018-06-27.abstract: Teachers’ unions could lose up to a third of their members and funding as a result of the Supreme Court ruling, labor experts say.
2018-06-27.snippet: Teachers’ unions could lose up to a third of their members and funding as a result of the Supreme Court ruling, labor experts say.

2018-06-27.abstract: The successor to the Hubble has had a series of mishaps during testing. An independent review board pushed back the launch for three years.

2018-06-27.abstract: Immigrants in detention will get hearings via video conference, after authorities said protests outside the Lower Manhattan court made the situation unsafe.
2018-06-27.snippet: Immigrants in detention will get hearings via video conference, after authorities said protests outside the Lower Manhattan court made the situation unsafe.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: In the middle of a national immigration firestorm over the Trump administration’s policy of separating children and parents at the southern border, and with the president tweeting that detained immigrants should be denied due process in the courts, the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency on Tuesday made an abrupt, unprecedented decision at its Lower Manhattan court: Detained immigrants in area jails would no longer be brought to court for hearings, but would have their cases heard via a video conference.
2018-06-27.headline_main: New Yorkers Facing Deportation Lose Their (Physical) Day in Court

2018-06-27.abstract: Children under the age of 5 must be reunited with their parents within 14 days, the judge said, and other minor children must be reunited within 30 days.
2018-06-27.snippet: Children under the age of 5 must be reunited with their parents within 14 days, the judge said, and other minor children must be reunited within 30 days.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trump administration officials said on Wednesday that it would be difficult to comply with the timetable in a federal court order requiring the reunification of migrant children and parents who were separated at the border.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Trump Administration Cites Difficulties in Meeting Judge’s Timetable for Family Reunification

2018-06-27.abstract: Facing two unnatural environments, these important pollinators are finding better niches to exploit in urban areas.

2018-06-27.abstract: “Squeezed: Why Our Families Can’t Afford America,” by Alissa Quart, is a timely book about the increasing number of people who feel profound economic vulnerability.
2018-06-27.snippet: “Squeezed: Why Our Families Can’t Afford America,” by Alissa Quart, is a timely book about the increasing number of people who feel profound economic vulnerability.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: It wasn’t long ago that the term “middle class” suggested security, conformity and often complacency — a cohort that was such a reliable feature of postwar American life that it attracted not just political pandering but also cultural ridicule. The stereotype included everyone from men in gray flannel suits to the slick professionals of “Thirtysomething,” stuck or smug in their world of bourgeois comforts.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Going for Broke, the Middle Class Goes Broke

Kennedy announced on Wednesday that he would retire this summer, setting in motion a furious fight over the future of the Supreme Court and giving President Trump the chance to put a conservative stamp on the American legal system for generations.

2018-06-27.abstract: With James Ford from Simian Mobile Disco helping shape the sounds, the group’s sixth album, “The Now Now,” takes on more private concerns.
2018-06-27.snippet: With James Ford from Simian Mobile Disco helping shape the sounds, the group’s sixth album, “The Now Now,” takes on more private concerns.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: I confess: I’ve never been able to sustain deep interest in the elaborate fictional universe of Gorillaz, the virtual, cartoon-character band conceived in 1998 by the English songwriter Damon Albarn and the comics artist Jamie Hewlett. Twenty years into Gorillaz’s career, Mr. Hewlett’s online visual chronicles have been inventive and fun, but Mr. Albarn’s songs have been deeper and more durable. Most often, Mr. Albarn’s music has been a counterpoint to the rest of Gorillaz’s presence: melancholy and introverted alongside Mr. Hewlett’s antic, allusion-laced animations. And it’s the melancholy that lingers.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Behind the Cartoon Gorillaz, Damon Albarn Is a Man Alone

2018-06-27.abstract: Our politics are cracking up over the density divide.
2018-06-27.snippet: Our politics are cracking up over the density divide.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The great, gradual migration of the human population from the countryside to the city has transformed the world, but we’ve barely begun to reckon with its political implications. Over generations, urbanization has sorted us on the traits — ethnicity, education level, personal temperament — that draw us toward cities or keep us away.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Why Do We Value Country Folk More Than City People?

2018-06-27.abstract: Engrossing and sometimes enraging, this documentary tells of triplets who, after being separately adopted at birth, were later reunited.
2018-06-27.snippet: Engrossing and sometimes enraging, this documentary tells of triplets who, after being separately adopted at birth, were later reunited.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The title “Three Identical Strangers” is somewhat of a giveaway in a documentary that’s best watched knowing as little as possible about its specifics. So, tread (and read) lightly! Engrossing, and sometimes enraging, the movie tells of triplets who, after being adopted separately at birth, were reunited by happenstance. None of the men — or their families — knew about the others, which naturally led to questions and has inspired the director Tim Wardle to turn their mysterious history into a detective story in reverse, one that begins with the seeming denouement (the happy reunion) and then moves back and forth across time.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Review: The Surreal, Heartbreaking Case of ‘Three Identical Strangers’

2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Congratulations, Mr. President: The Supreme Court has ruled that your third attempt at a travel ban is within the scope of your constitutional prerogatives. To nobody’s surprise, you trumpeted the court’s decision as “a moment of profound vindication following months of hysterical commentary from the media and Democratic politicians who refuse to do what it takes to secure our border and our country.”
2018-06-27.headline_main: How, Exactly, Does This Travel Ban Keep Us Safe, Mr. President?

2018-06-27.abstract: With cars being banished from the drives, New Yorkers get to taste an urban oasis that’s closer to nature.
2018-06-27.snippet: With cars being banished from the drives, New Yorkers get to taste an urban oasis that’s closer to nature.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Next time you step from a city street into a traffic-free urban park, taste the air. The leafy tang will purge your palate of the acrid, oily residue of vehicle exhaust. Now listen to the changed soundscape. Away from the smothering mire of engine noise, trees give voice to the wind’s moods, and bird songs weave aural textures in the air.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Central Park, Now More Delicious

2018-06-27.abstract: Simon Porte Jacquemus introduces his men’s collection in Marseille, 500 miles and a world away from Paris Fashion Week.
2018-06-27.snippet: Simon Porte Jacquemus introduces his men’s collection in Marseille, 500 miles and a world away from Paris Fashion Week.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: If France Tourism needs a new spokesman, it could do worse than Simon Porte Jacquemus. Even in our age of global fashion, global communication, global everything, he maintains the earthy terroir of his motherland. For his new men’s collection, he bypassed Paris Fashion Week, where he shows his women’s wear, and headed down to Marseille, on the Mediterranean coast.
2018-06-27.headline_main: A Little Bad Taste by the Sea

2018-06-27.abstract: At this site, now closing because of rising rent, New York critics and filmmakers met and bantered at tens of thousands of screenings since 1987.
2018-06-27.snippet: At this site, now closing because of rising rent, New York critics and filmmakers met and bantered at tens of thousands of screenings since 1987.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: To most observers, the closure of two movie screening rooms that shared a block near Times Square with a strip club and a souvenir boutique might seem like just another symptom of a changing neighborhood. But for film critics in New York, the shuttering of Magno Review 1 and 2, which will show their last movies today after 31 years in operation, is significant.
2018-06-27.headline_main: So Long to an Old (and, O.K., Shabby) Friend: Magno Screening Rooms

2018-06-27.abstract: The Supreme Court ruling weakens public unions, which have been crucial defenders of rights for queer people.
2018-06-27.snippet: The Supreme Court ruling weakens public unions, which have been crucial defenders of rights for queer people.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court just dealt a staggering blow to the L.G.B.T. rights movement. And no, it had nothing to do with wedding cake. While the eyes of most L.G.B.T. advocates this term were concentrated on Masterpiece Cakeshop v. Colorado Civil Rights Commission, the legal ruling was decidedly narrow. The court’s 5-4 decision today in Janus v. American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees, however, will have immediate and lasting implications for the livelihoods of queer people.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Janus Is This Term’s Worst L.G.B.T. Ruling

2018-06-27.snippet: The Supreme Court’s decision imperils public-sector unions. Whether they survive will be up to them.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Conservatives on the Supreme Court have been signaling for years that they would like to destroy public-sector unions. On Wednesday, they handed down a ruling that aims to do just that. But the justices and right-wing groups that pushed for this outcome could soon find that it will not be so easy to suppress teachers, social workers and other government employees who in recent months have taken to the streets to demand raises and better working conditions.

2018-06-27.abstract: The World Cup will depart Volgograd on Thursday after a final first-round game in this city along the Volga River. What will remain are all the echoes of the past.

This is Mother Russia, and buried at her feet lie the remains of tens of thousands of casualties of the Battle of Stalingrad, the conflict that will forever define this city.

2018-06-27.abstract: Lorena Hickok and Eleanor Roosevelt are among the apparitions in a bittersweet comedy about a lesbian reconciling different parts of her adult identity.
2018-06-27.snippet: Lorena Hickok and Eleanor Roosevelt are among the apparitions in a bittersweet comedy about a lesbian reconciling different parts of her adult identity.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: In a classroom at an all-girls Roman Catholic high school in New Orleans, the ghost of Lorena Hickok surveys the situation. A journalist, she was Eleanor Roosevelt’s devoted friend and quite possibly her great love. If their relationship was a romance — and in Christina Quintana’s bittersweet new comedy “Scissoring,” it was indeed — it remained as hidden from the public as Franklin D. Roosevelt’s wheelchair.

2018-06-27.snippet: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy served as the decisive vote in several closely watched cases during his tenure. Here are some major decisions where he left his mark.

His retirement at the end of next month will pave the way for a contentious fight to determine the future direction of the Supreme Court.

2018-06-27.abstract: Seized under an assimilation program, she and two other Aboriginal girls made their way home across hundreds of miles, a feat depicted in “Rabbit-Proof Fence.”

2018-06-27.headline_main: Daisy Kadibil, 95, Whose Australia Trek Inspired a Film, Dies

2018-06-27.abstract: He provided a crucial fifth vote to the court’s conservative wing, but he sometimes voted against it, especially on abortion.
2018-06-27.snippet: He provided a crucial fifth vote to the court’s conservative wing, but he sometimes voted against it, especially on abortion.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: For more than a dozen years, Justice Anthony Kennedy stood at the center of the Supreme Court. He moved the court to the right, but while he often provided a crucial fifth vote to the court’s conservative wing, Justice Kennedy sometimes voted against it. And he picked a few causes that liberals cherish, making him their occasional, if fickle, guardian angel.
2018-06-27.headline_main: We’re About to Find Out How Bad It Will Get Without Justice Kennedy

2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: OK, this is a bit self-indulgent, aimed at a very narrow audience, and maybe also whiny too. But via Mark Thoma I see that Nicholas Gruen has a celebratory piece on Max Corden that for some reason is largely devoted to a sort of back-handed attack on yours truly. Money quote: “I think of Krugman as about the most brilliant and useful economist we have. But his most brilliant work wasn’t useful, and his most useful work isn’t brilliant.”
2018-06-27.headline_main: Uses and Abuses of Economic Formalism (Wonkish and Self-referential)

2018-06-27.abstract: Her research undermined the prevailing theory that Northern Republicans and newly enfranchised former slaves created a tragedy for the South.
2018-06-27.snippet: Her research undermined the prevailing theory that Northern Republicans and newly enfranchised former slaves created a tragedy for the South.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Willie Lee Rose, a historian who upended the scholarly consensus of her time by shifting the primary blame for the failure of Reconstruction after the Civil War from freed slaves and Northern interlopers to irresolute federal officials, died on June 20 in Baltimore. She was 91.
2018-06-27.headline_main: Willie Lee Rose, Historian of Reconstruction, Dies at 91

2018-06-27.abstract: In an episode with extremely little dialogue, Elisabeth Moss carried what was easily among the show’s best hours to date.
2018-06-27.snippet: In an episode with extremely little dialogue, Elisabeth Moss carried what was easily among the show’s best hours to date.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Can we just pause for a second to appreciate Elisabeth Moss? She isn’t just the star of “The Handmaid’s Tale”; she is its heart, soul and, above all, its endlessly expressive face. It is her physical performance that digs the show out of narrative ruts and sells its most unconvincing twists. Her Offred can look meek and subservient or utterly dejected, but the character’s core is solid steel. Lest we take Moss for granted, this week’s episode, “Holly,” was a reminder that her work on this series comprises some of the most empathetic and nuanced acting in any medium.
2018-06-27.headline_main: ‘The Handmaid’s Tale’ Season 2, Episode 11 Recap: We’re Still Here

2018-06-27.abstract: Seismologists say shaking from earthquakes in some West Coast cities will be much stronger than previously thought.
2018-06-27.snippet: Seismologists say shaking from earthquakes in some West Coast cities will be much stronger than previously thought.
2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In their quest to make tall buildings safe during earthquakes, engineers have for decades relied on calculations that represent the tremors and convulsions that a building can endure. Some of the world’s top earthquake experts now say the projections significantly underestimate the severity of shaking that buildings in several West Coast cities are likely to undergo during earthquakes.
2018-06-27.headline_main: A Seismic Change in Predicting How Earthquakes Will Shake Tall Buildings

2018-06-27.lead_paragraph: Thousands of people gathered outside a hockey arena in South Florida on Wednesday, waiting to get a glimpse of the rapper XXXTentacion. Avid fans wore show-merch T-shirts and stood in long lines to enter the arena, the BB&T Center in Sunrise, just a few miles from where the artist was born. But they weren’t there for one of his concerts. They were there for his memorial.

Clue is at 56A, look at the grid, find the entry for 56A, write it in. It’s a solving aid, a crutch, is all the numbering really is.

2018-06-28.snippet: Jan Banning sought out the local meeting places and day-to-day operations of the dwindling communist parties around the world.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: In the 20th century, communism swept across a third of the world and challenged global capitalism. In the 21st century, the movement’s power is greatly diminished. Only five countries — China, Cuba, Laos, North Korea and Vietnam — claim to be communist states. Few, if any, of them embody the ideology Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels described in “The Communist Manifesto.”

2018-06-28.abstract: Selected by Rita Dove.
2018-06-28.snippet: Selected by Rita Dove.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: How fitting that in the month of American independence we come to celebrate the outgoing editor for this space. Terrance Hayes has, with more than a bit of shade, created his own brand of hip-hop sonnet. Just as the United States are multifarious and contradictory and complicated, he went on until he had accumulated an entire collection of sonnets, all bar none with the same title. Truly, a tour de force! “The song must be cultural, confessional, clear” — a pithy ars poetica for our volatile age. Hayes’s word plays, from homonyms to the transmogrification of Sturm und Drang into “storm and drum,” are less linguistic jokes than wry descriptions of an Anglo-America that has taken the historical discourse of Western civilization to its own brash level. And in case you were hoping to be let off easy, beware: The last line may stick in your throat. Selected by Rita Dove
2018-06-28.headline_main: Poem: American Sonnet for My Past and Future Assassin

2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: Is it the influx of immigrants from countries like Myanmar and Bhutan or the uptick in cultural investments? The transformation of the waterfront or the revitalization of local institutions? Or is it simply the food? Like many small American cities, Buffalo, which had early booms from various industries, including railways, shipyards and steel manufacturing, is shedding its rusty roots and experiencing a bona fide renaissance. No longer merely the portal to nearby Niagara Falls, Buffalo is a modern and multifaceted city, more than ready for its moment.

2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: Even though Central Park, like the rest of Manhattan, is largely man-made, not natural, it is a place to experience in person, not secondhand through images, regardless of their authenticity, nor through narratives, no matter how illustrative.

2018-06-28.abstract: Talismans and amulets — objects believed to have magical powers — were once part of any self-respecting doctor’s medicine bag.
2018-06-28.snippet: Talismans and amulets — objects believed to have magical powers — were once part of any self-respecting doctor’s medicine bag.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: The velvety rabbit with big floppy ears and a silver tiara came to me 34 years ago with a name tag that read, “Fairy God Bunny.” That was when I was in my mid-20s and had cancer. For five years I carried this rabbit with me to the hospital for labs, CT scans and X-rays. I was never shy about introducing it to anyone, nor did I feel hypocritical, even though I was a 26-year-old Ph.D. candidate.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Do You Believe in Magic? I Do

2018-06-28.abstract: In “Damnation Island,” Stacy Horn traces the appalling history of the East River institutions where 19th-century New York exiled its undesirables.
2018-06-28.snippet: In “Damnation Island,” Stacy Horn traces the appalling history of the East River institutions where 19th-century New York exiled its undesirables.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: DAMNATION ISLAND Poor, Sick, Mad & Criminal in 19th-Century New York By Stacy Horn Illustrated. 284 pp. Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $27.95.
2018-06-28.headline_main: A Dumping Ground for the Poor, the Criminal and the Mad

2018-06-28.abstract: When Ryan Baylock ran out of roommates to fill his Fort Greene rental, he crossed the Hudson and found affordable options in Jersey City.

2018-06-28.abstract: Contrasting approaches to France’s national playwright have been on view this month.
2018-06-28.snippet: Contrasting approaches to France’s national playwright have been on view this month.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Molière has long been the patron saint of French theater. His plays, from “Tartuffe” to “The Misanthrope,” are studied in schools here; the country’s most prestigious theater awards are named the Molières. But nowadays, high-profile French theater-makers are reluctant to tackle his plays.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Molière the Entertainer vs. Serious Molière

2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: It is hardly news that President Trump has deliberately provoked liberal outrage, as a candidate and as president. But in case anyone is still wondering whether his inflammatory language is the result of design or impulse, recent comments from current and former White House strategists are revealing.

2018-06-28.abstract: China’s push to dominate the tech industry globally is drawing resistance from the U.S., and that has markets bracing for a techno trade war.
2018-06-28.snippet: China’s push to dominate the tech industry globally is drawing resistance from the U.S., and that has markets bracing for a techno trade war.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: Arriving in Beijing last month, I knew I would not be able to connect to Google, Facebook or Uber. As strange as it was to go without these staples of online life in the West, it was even stranger to find that local Chinese didn’t seem to feel deprived at all. They search through Baidu, get their social media fix on WeChat, hail rides on Didi, curate news through sites like Toutiao. And while they know Beijing is watching, they accept this surveillance as normal.
2018-06-28.headline_main: The Coming Tech Battle With China

2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — To hear it from the White House, America’s southern border is a war zone. Things look a lot different up close. Here in El Paso, local governments collaborate closely with federal agencies in the United States and Mexico to ensure that our ports of entry — bridges connecting the two countries — can effectively and safely move more than 10 million people and $90 billion in trade back and forth each year.
2018-06-28.headline_main: There Is No Immigration Crisis in El Paso

2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia approved sweeping national security legislation on Thursday that bans foreign interference in politics, stiffens the punishment for leaking classified information and makes it a crime to damage Australia’s economic relations with another country.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Australian Law Targets Foreign Interference. China Is Not Pleased.

2018-06-28.abstract: The timing gives both parties a potent issue heading into the midterm elections. Here’s what we can expect in the coming months.

2018-06-28.abstract: Four young opioid addicts in West Virginia tackle recovery and sober living in this raw and moving documentary.
2018-06-28.snippet: Four young opioid addicts in West Virginia tackle recovery and sober living in this raw and moving documentary.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: Opening a wider window into a world many of us know only from news reports and the long-running television series “Intervention,” Elaine McMillion Sheldon’s “Recovery Boys” tracks four young opioid addicts through the chutes and ladders of recovery and sober living.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Review: For These ‘Recovery Boys,’ Sobriety Is a Steep Climb

2018-06-28.abstract: Jessica Chastain and Michael Greyeyes are marvelous in this gorgeous, romanticized tale of the 19th-century artist who painted Sitting Bull’s portrait.
2018-06-28.snippet: Jessica Chastain and Michael Greyeyes are marvelous in this gorgeous, romanticized tale of the 19th-century artist who painted Sitting Bull’s portrait.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: The best way to enjoy Susanna White’s “Woman Walks Ahead” — a fictionalized account of an event in the life of the 19th-century artist and Native American rights activist Catherine Weldon — is to view it less as a historical record than a fish-out-of-water romance. Albeit one that gets no more physical than a desperate cuddle.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Review: A ‘Woman Walks Ahead,’ and Sitting Bull Stands Up

2018-06-28.abstract: Drool-worthy confectionery expresses unspoken emotions in first feature from the writer and director Ofir Raul Graizer.

2018-06-28.headline_main: Review: A German ‘Cakemaker’ and an Israeli Widow Share Loss and Cookies

2018-06-28.abstract: “This Is Congo” aims to deliver a portrait of the Democratic Republic of Congo from the ground up.
2018-06-28.snippet: “This Is Congo” aims to deliver a portrait of the Democratic Republic of Congo from the ground up.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: A making-of featurette about the difficulties of filming the documentary “This Is Congo” might be as harrowing as the movie itself. At times the filmmakers get terrifyingly close to live fire.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Review: In ‘This Is Congo,’ Four Lives Shaken by Conflict

2018-06-28.abstract: Matt Osterman’s allegorical thriller, written by its star, Cleopatra Coleman, flirts with topicality on several fronts.
2018-06-28.snippet: Matt Osterman’s allegorical thriller, written by its star, Cleopatra Coleman, flirts with topicality on several fronts.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: “Hover” won’t be remembered as a milestone of paranoid science fiction, but it may be the first example of its genre in which the heroine, wise to a conspiracy, gets to yell “Why are you following me?” at a self-driving car. On the evidence, it’s difficult to stage such a scene without getting a bad laugh, just as it’s tough to film a car chase in which the good guys dodge sentient drones without having it look silly.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Review: In ‘Hover,’ the Drone Tech Isn’t All There

2018-06-28.abstract: Lisa Immordino Vreeland’s new documentary is about Cecil Beaton, the British dandy, photographer and theatrical designer.
2018-06-28.snippet: Lisa Immordino Vreeland’s new documentary is about Cecil Beaton, the British dandy, photographer and theatrical designer.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: Was Cecil Beaton, the photographer, artist, diarist and theatrical designer who chronicled, and was influenced by, several periods of artistic and social upheaval in the 20th century, the last dandy? The documentary, “Love, Cecil,” directed with energy and affection by Lisa Immordino Vreeland, doesn’t grapple with that question, and doesn’t have to; almost 40 years after Beaton’s 1980 death at age 76, no aesthete has come close to duplicating his output or his impact.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Review: In ‘Love, Cecil,’ an Aesthete Ahead of His Time

2018-06-28.abstract: Ruth Wilson gives a tough, traumatized performance in Clio Barnard’s Yorkshire-set psychodrama.
2018-06-28.snippet: Ruth Wilson gives a tough, traumatized performance in Clio Barnard’s Yorkshire-set psychodrama.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: The Yorkshire depicted in Clio Barnard’s third feature, “Dark River,” has much in common with that of Francis Lee’s recent triumph, “God’s Own Country”: a place of hard labor and lowering skies, of bleating sheep and repressed sexuality. Yet even in the swelling canon of British rural miserabilism, this unrelentingly intense psychodrama burrows beneath the skin.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Review: A ‘Dark River’ of Abuse Separates a Brother and Sister from Their Inheritance

2018-06-28.abstract: This basketball comedy is amusing and kindhearted, but strangely bland.
2018-06-28.snippet: This basketball comedy is amusing and kindhearted, but strangely bland.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that you can say, “Shaquille O’Neal was the best actor in that movie.” And yet that may well be true in the case of “Uncle Drew,” a genuinely unusual exercise in screen comedy directed by Charles Stone III that features Mr. O’Neal and several other N.B.A. superstars, both retired and active.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Review: In ‘Uncle Drew,’ N.B.A. Stars Keep Dunking With Age

2018-06-28.abstract: The country has jailed hundreds of conscientious objectors every year, mostly Jehovah’s Witnesses. Now such men will be given the option of civilian service.

2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: It’s 1965, and two well-heeled British men share a fussy lunch where they surprisingly each confess a history of gay sexual encounters. “My wife insists that ‘gay’ means happy,” one groans. “I think she’s absolutely right,” the other says. “And I intend to be very happy — very many times in my life.”

2018-06-28.abstract: The identity of the man who shoved a 33-year-old pedestrian into the path of a bus will probably remain a mystery, as the authorities said all leads had been exhausted.
2018-06-28.snippet: The identity of the man who shoved a 33-year-old pedestrian into the path of a bus will probably remain a mystery, as the authorities said all leads had been exhausted.

2018-06-28.snippet: For the next two episodes, we hand the microphones over to our Asian-American colleagues, friends, and listeners to hear about their experiences with racism.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: This week and next, we’re doing something different. After witnessing an awful instance of anti-Asian racism at a movie theater, we couldn’t stop thinking about how this type of racism is rampant in American culture, both on the screen and off. At first, we wanted to talk about it. But then, we realized that we needed to listen.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Asian-Americans Talk About Racism, and We Listen — Part 1

2018-06-28.abstract: Would you expect anything less from Chrissy Teigen’s husband?
2018-06-28.snippet: Would you expect anything less from Chrissy Teigen’s husband?
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: On a recent Wednesday afternoon, the singer and songwriter John Legend was at the Soho House in Malibu, Calif., his jean-jacketed back to the Pacific Ocean, his left hand around a glass of rosé that he helped create. He was ruminating about the global uptick in wine consumption — the millennial’s alcoholic beverage of choice, according to studies and articles galore.
2018-06-28.headline_main: John Legend Plunges Into the Celebrity Rosé Business

2018-06-28.abstract: An atheist wonders whether she should talk to her granddaughter about religion.
2018-06-28.snippet: An atheist wonders whether she should talk to her granddaughter about religion.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: My daughter and son-in-law send their 6-year-old to a parochial school. They are not particularly religious; I am an atheist. The little girl asked recently why another child wasn’t baptized. Her mother said, “Some people do that, others don’t.” When my sister died, the girl asked if she was in heaven. My daughter said, “Some people don’t believe in heaven.” I’ve been going along with this approach. But at some point, won’t it be in my grandchild’s best interests for me to explain that belief in a fictional deity is a poor substitute for science and rationality?
2018-06-28.headline_main: Grandma, What Do You Mean There’s No God?

2018-06-28.abstract: Gerard & Kelly weave the linked careers of Philip Johnson, Mies van der Rohe and R.M. Schindler into a performance.
2018-06-28.snippet: Gerard & Kelly weave the linked careers of Philip Johnson, Mies van der Rohe and R.M. Schindler into a performance.

2018-06-28.headline_main: In Three Famous Houses, Modern Living Unwinds

2018-06-28.abstract: The chef of the bright yellow food truck hopes to turn the food of her childhood into an American staple.
2018-06-28.snippet: The chef of the bright yellow food truck hopes to turn the food of her childhood into an American staple.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: Injera is a certainty at every Ethiopian meal and the measure of every Ethiopian restaurant: floppy, featherweight flatbread as thin as a kerchief, with the sepia tinge of an old photograph. One side is smooth while the other has almost more holes than dough, from the bubbles that swell and pop as the batter settles on the mitad (griddle). In Amharic they are known as ain, or eyes, and the more of them, the better.
2018-06-28.headline_main: At Makina Cafe, Ethiopian Takeaway With Buoyant Injera

2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: Sometimes it seems as if we’re living under a constant barrage of heavy news. But it isn’t all bad out there. This feature is meant to send you into the weekend with a smile, or at least a lighter heart. Want to get The Week in Good News by email? Here’s the sign-up.

2018-06-28.abstract: The three-part mini-series starring Hugh Grant is coming to Amazon. Here’s a primer on the lurid tale behind it and the sensational press of its time.
2018-06-28.snippet: The three-part mini-series starring Hugh Grant is coming to Amazon. Here’s a primer on the lurid tale behind it and the sensational press of its time.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: When the three-part mini-series “A Very English Scandal” hits Amazon Prime on June 29, it will be received by a much different audience than the one that rapturously watched it on BBC One last month. That audience was presumably much better-versed on the scandal that inspired the series (and the John Preston true-crime novel it was adapted from), which involved a closeted gay member of Parliament named Jeremy Thorpe, a male model, blackmail and a murder plot.
2018-06-28.headline_main: ‘Sex, Cash and Death’: The Story Behind ‘A Very English Scandal’

2018-06-28.abstract: He was a champion for equality, but he left plenty of room for people to undo the progress he made.
2018-06-28.snippet: He was a champion for equality, but he left plenty of room for people to undo the progress he made.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: In 30 years on the Supreme Court — the past 13 as the swing justice — Justice Anthony Kennedy has been the decisive vote in cases on issues ranging from abortion to affirmative action. Yet his legacy will be defined primarily by his opinions in the area of gay rights, where he wrote the major majority opinions expansively reading the Constitution to protect gay Americans.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Without Kennedy, the Future of Gay Rights Is Fragile

2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: A former aide to Roger J. Stone Jr., the longtime Trump adviser and self-described “dirty trickster,” was subpoenaed to appear before the grand jury hearing evidence in the Russia investigation and to hand over documents, and his lawyer moved on Thursday to quash it in court.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Ex-Aide to Roger Stone Is Subpoenaed in Russia Investigation

2018-06-28.abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
2018-06-28.snippet: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: It’s been an active week, politically speaking — they all are, these days — and with the Fourth of July around the corner, politics are front and center in our recommended titles. From Terrance Hayes, there’s a poetry collection sparked by Donald Trump’s election; from Ben Rhodes, a memoir of his time as a key adviser in the Obama White House; and from Stephen Greenblatt, a pointed consideration of the political leaders in Shakespeare’s plays that might call to mind, reassuringly or not, the opening lines of Sonnet 59: “If there be nothing new, but that which is / Hath been before …”
2018-06-28.headline_main: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week

2018-06-28.abstract: Adnan Januzaj curled in a left-footed shot in the second half to give Belgium a 1-0 victory over England.
2018-06-28.snippet: Adnan Januzaj curled in a left-footed shot in the second half to give Belgium a 1-0 victory over England.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Adnan Januzaj curled in a left-footed shot in the second half to give a second-string Belgium a 1-0 victory over a second-string England on Thursday. The win continued Belgium’s strong start to the World Cup — it joined Croatia and Uruguay as the only teams to win all three games in the group stage — but it set the Red Devils on a potentially far more difficult path in the knockouts.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Belgium Beats England, but Faces Tougher World Cup Bracket

2018-06-28.abstract: China’s stock market has fallen into a bear market and the currency is tumbling on worries about tariffs and China’s efforts to rein in domestic debt.

2018-06-28.abstract: Ben Foster and Thomasin Harcourt McKenzie play father and daughter in the latest movie from Debra Granik, the director of “Winter’s Bone.”
2018-06-28.snippet: Ben Foster and Thomasin Harcourt McKenzie play father and daughter in the latest movie from Debra Granik, the director of “Winter’s Bone.”
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: The dense green foliage that surrounds the man and his daughter in “Leave No Trace” seems to hold them as if in sheltering arms. It is a blissful, serene scene, one set to the sounds of human movement and the familiar natural buzzing, chirping and whirring. The tall mossy trees and carpet of ferns suggest that it’s the Pacific Northwest, somewhere deep in the woods. Father and daughter seem to be camping — there are tarps as well as a fire pit, though no car or other people in sight — but then the girl sits on a plastic milk crate and the two settle into the site they call home.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Review: ‘Leave No Trace’ Is a Very American Story About Survival

2018-06-28.abstract: Japanese-Americans who lived through internment camps in the 1940s see parallels in ruling that upheld President Trump’s travel ban.
2018-06-28.snippet: Japanese-Americans who lived through internment camps in the 1940s see parallels in ruling that upheld President Trump’s travel ban.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The actor George Takei, who was 5 years old when he was sent with his family to a camp in Arkansas, was rehearsing for a role when his husband interrupted him with some news this week from the Supreme Court.

But on Thursday, the ever-intensifying skirmishes between Deputy Attorney General Rod J. Rosenstein and conservative House Republicans broke into an ugly public fight.

2018-06-28.abstract: Richardson, whose workplace behavior was first exposed by Sports Illustrated in December, is in the process of selling the team for $2.2 billion.

2018-06-28.abstract: The Children’s Museum of Manhattan has opened “Art, Artists & You,” an exhibition that gives four adult artists residencies and opportunities to mentor visitors.
2018-06-28.snippet: The Children’s Museum of Manhattan has opened “Art, Artists & You,” an exhibition that gives four adult artists residencies and opportunities to mentor visitors.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: A young girl with waist-length golden hair entered a small room where a woman sat at a spinning wheel. Fascinated, the girl approached the device swiftly. Although the scene was in a modern museum, it had the feel of a fairy tale. A powerful spell had indeed been cast, and it was working: Amelia Salenger, the 4-year-old visitor, was becoming enchanted by contemporary art.
2018-06-28.headline_main: Kids Don’t Just See Art at This Show. They Work With the Artists, Too.

2018-06-28.abstract: The mortality rate flattens among the oldest of the old, a study of elderly Italians concludes, suggesting that the oldest humans have not yet reached the limits of life span.
2018-06-28.snippet: The mortality rate flattens among the oldest of the old, a study of elderly Italians concludes, suggesting that the oldest humans have not yet reached the limits of life span.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: Since 1900, average life expectancy around the globe has more than doubled, thanks to better public health, sanitation and food supplies. But a new study of long-lived Italians indicates that we have yet to reach the upper bound of human longevity.

2018-06-28.abstract: James Schwab quit his job because he did not want to lie on behalf of the Trump administration. Three months later, agents knocked on his door.

2018-06-28.abstract: Ahead of his first major show, Wendell Dayton welcomes T to his home studio — and the lawn that has doubled as his gallery in the meantime.
2018-06-28.snippet: Ahead of his first major show, Wendell Dayton welcomes T to his home studio — and the lawn that has doubled as his gallery in the meantime.
2018-06-28.lead_paragraph: At the age of 80, the sculptor Wendell Dayton is having his first major show, a six-decade survey of his work at the Los Angeles gallery Blum & Poe. Until now, Dayton had mainly exhibited his abstract creations in a sculpture park of his own making, in the unassuming corner of the San Fernando Valley where he lives and works. The brittle yellow grass of the two-acre lawn surrounding his low-slung white house is dotted with abstract monuments assembled from sheets of stainless steel. Some of the pieces are almost 50 years old, yet Dayton’s conservation routine is blissfully minimal — the beauty of stainless steel is that it never rusts. “It just flies along, man,” Dayton says in his surfer drawl, which belies his Pacific Northwest roots.
2018-06-28.headline_main: A California Sculptor Gets His Moment in the Sun, at Age 80
